reviewText: The Expendables is a fun ride, but a disappointing one.  I won’t say it is bad.  I had fun with the movie.  However, it didn’t really deliver what they promised, or at least not fully.  This film is basically The Statham and Stallone show while the others are minor side characters or just have brief cameos.  The action is good, but the film does suffer from some shaky-cam.  This film just did not live up to its potential.As I said the film is fun.  When the action is there it is good for the most part despite the shaky-cam.  Sylvester Stallone and Jason Statham bring their A-game.  They do a competent job acting-wise, the action scenes involving them are pretty good, and they do work off each other well.  It’s a good thing they do work well together because they pretty much have to carry the film for a major chunk.  Without their chemistry this film would probably suck.However, as I said previously, those two really hog the majority of the spotlight.  You have other action stars like Jet Li, Dolph Lundgren, and Terry Crews who do not get that much screen time.  You see everyone together in the beginning action scene, and then they all just disappear leaving just Stallone and Statham for the entire middle portion.  They then all come back at the end for the final battle.  Then you have people like Bruce Willis, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Mickey Rourke who just make brief cameos.  Rourke appears more than the other two but he doesn’t do anything.  Schwarzenegger I can understand at the time but the other two really have no excuse.Overall, if you want a fun action film with Stallone and Statham teamed up you will enjoy this film.  However, this film promised a union of so many of the big action stars.  We see them, but most are not in the film very much while others just make cameos.  When they are there it’s fun, but still.  This is basically Statham and Stallone’s movie.  Again, I don’t dislike the film.  I had fun with it, but I still found it a bit underwhelming.  Thankfully Expendables 2 and, hopefully, Expendables 3, improved upon the problems of this one.

reviewText: ... based on all the negative reviews from all the critics bashing this film up one side and down the other.Folks say this film hasn't much of a plot; I say that isn't so.It's called mini-plot.There are three kinds of plots:  Arch-plot, mini-plot, and anti-plot (see Robert McKee's excellent "Story" for a detailed explanation of what makes for a great screenplay, along with more excellent discourse on character, plot, etc.).  "The Expendables" is mini-plot (conversely, something like "Saving Private Ryan" would fall under the arch-plot umbrella, for example).There isn't any great objective to be obtained here, like blowing up the Death Star; nor is there any "oh, now they all understand, and isn't great that they're all better people" moment either.  What we have is Barney Ross; we drop into his life, go along with him a ways, share an adventure, and then, once he's rescued the girl, we part ways.If this isn't your cup of tea, then "The Expendables" isn't for you.  However, if you want to see a great action picture that does, indeed, establish camraderie between yourself, Barney, and others in the cast, then you'll enjoy this film.Stallone has developed into a first-rate action director; one need only look as far as the recent films "Rocky Balboa" and "Rambo: Burmese" to see this.  He's quite skilled behind a camara; one might even call him an artist.(That stands to reason, since he's delivered some excellent paintings over the years.  Don't believe me?  It's called "google".)Stallone has an eye for a great scene; he always know just exactly how to use the camara to bring his audience right into the center of the action.  The action choreography is spot-on first-rate here; it's just impossible not to have fun watching this film.Personally, I didn't have any issues with the dialog here, since tough guys do tend to talk like this.  I will say that hopefully, as this series continues, Stallone will flex his screenwriting muscles a bit more; "Rocky Balboa" contained some of the best dialog he's written in years, so hopefully, as he writes additional material for this series, he'll invest himself a bit more in what his characters have to say.(Personally, I think Stallone chose this vehicle because at this point in his career, he wants to go out strong, and yet he also wants to re-establish himself as a major-box office draw.  This will, in turn, provide an opportunity for such artistic endeavors as "Poe", and also his possible upcoming portrayal of John Gotti.  In order to get people interested in those projects, he's got to get them in the habit of going to see his movies again. "RB", "R:B", and "TE" provide a pathway to do just that.)If you're looking for a well-directed action film, look no further.  I very much enjoyed this picture, and am looking forward to a sequel.

reviewText: Stallone et al deliver a throwback homage to the action movie genre. Trying to rekindle some of the movie styles that have these days become post Matrix, Bourne style choppy fast camera fights and dramas, that you need to replay to enjoy.The movie isn't bad, on the one hand it's totally shameless with the line up, adding Schwarzenegger and Willis to the "Starring" line up is a joke really, they are on screen for about 3 minutes of dialogue, and that's it, hardly noteworthy. Surprised they didn't have someone watching an old movie clip so they could have added "starring Steve McQueen and Paul Newman" to the line up, but I digress.It's a fairly simple story, the movie opens with an unconnected rescue scene to introduce us to Stallone's team of "Expendables" dealing with some Somalia pirates on a ship somewhere with hostages (very topical)plenty of gun play and action to whet the appetite so to speak.We then get a deeper perspective of the main characters, particularly Stallone and Statham, as they undertake a "overthrow dictator and rescue innocents" mission in some made up island "in the gulf" - In the gulf? - which gulf, I mean come on people, details please even if it's made up.Of course the mission is a lie, to aid CIA drug shenanigans, and the team have to figure out the good guys from the bad guys, and so on.For me, here's where the film split, and annoyingly so.If you want to make an out and out testosterone flick (the original Predator, or Rambo springs to mind) do so. Don't add in padding scenes like Mickey Rourke getting all misty eyed and introspective about old missions, and the mental and emotional cost of "war is hell".Ultimately, the film tries not to be a mindless action drama, but after the meandering script dips it's toe into heartfelt character building, the movie explodes into a killing spree where just about everyone gets beaten, shot or blown up in the last 20 minutes anyway.They are a few moments of levity, some tongue in cheek action sequences, and some downright good action scenes, but it felt like Stallone couldn't make up his mind between action, and a thinking mans drama, and ended up delivering neither.Statham carries the whole movie for me, most of the other characters are in there for just the fighting scenes, and have little character development, but then again didn't really need any I suppose.It's an OK movie, definitely worth seeing, to find out what all your friends who have seen it are chatting about, but not destined to be a classic I fancy.Stallone has proved if nothing else that he's pretty good these days in the executive producers chair, maybe he should there. 3 stars

reviewText: It's been called "the best action movie of the year." It's been the #1 movie in the country two weeks in a row! So it must be really good, right? Well, it's actually a pretty basic action flick. The plot is uncomplicated and straight-to-the-point. For some, that sounds great to them. The ensemble of Stallone, Statham, Rourke, Couture, Lundgren, Li, Crews, Roberts, and Austin (plus cameos by Willis and Schwarzenegger) do a wonderful job with the acting and blowing up body parts of bad guys. However, the story was written merely for an action purpose. There is an unbelievable part to the film near the end between partners-in-crime, the General (David Zayas) and baddie James Munroe (Roberts); I won't get specific so as not to spoil it. But, it's just not believable. Of course, the action is unrealistic but that's expected in any action flick. But this interaction with the General and Munroe makes the film -- particularly the ending -- a bit hard to swallow.Overall, "The Expendables" is a good film. I enjoyed it and liked all the action. The characters were well played and I am looking forward to the sequel that I heard is already in the works. However, I enjoyedThe A-Teama lot more! Maybe it's because of my sense of nostalgia, or maybe it's 'cause I think Liam Neeson rocks. Either way, I enjoyed it better. But, again, "The Expendables" is no pushover (Stallone does a great job both in front of the camera and behind it), and I would recommend any action fan to see this as soon as possible.

reviewText: The Expendables is an example of false marketing. We have a fabulous myriad of action actors all claiming top billing. I expected to see a troupe of guys kicking butt in some dumb steroid-filled action frenzy. I was mistaken.This film belongs entirely to Sylvester Stallone and Jason Statham. Why are the other guys even there? Statham and Stallone are about the only characters to have anything to really do with moving the plot forward, going together to an island to free a girl from a tyranny. Which is fine, but what about Jet Li? He basically does nothing but complain about not getting paid enough. Bruce Willis? He appears for about a total of 60 seconds, barely even enough to qualify as supporting actor, let alone top billing. Even Mickey Rourke does nothing but sit around making tattoos and lamenting his lost humanity. In any other situation I would have welcomed such exposition, but what about all the rest?The Expendables does have its fair few action scenes, naturally. The film opens up pretty much in your face, with our heroes rescuing hostages from a pirate boat, and in quite a macho fashion too. I thought the rest of the movie would be like that. We do have a fight scene on a basketball court and a fast-paced fight in the trenches of a palace, with heavy adrenaline rush. I knew the movie was aiming for this, and it is an entertaining enough action movie, just without any real punch like, say, all of Arnold Schwarzenegger's action movies (arguably the king of action movies, and he appears for even less screen time than Willis, and then in the role of a politician. How the mighty have fallen).What annoys me about The Expendables is that it promised us an all-star extravaganza of actors and most of the time that just isn't the truth. Most of the actors are barely even there. They should just have marketed this as a buddy picture between Stallone and Statham, because that's basically what The Expendables is. I'd have more respect for it then.
summary: Not What It Says It Is

reviewText: The Expendables is a 'so-so' movie, but is loaded with action stars.  The great thing is that the director understood that with many action stars you don't really want them to talk as much as have them just doing action sequences. That part is actually the diamond in the rough for this film.  That one scene is deserving of an oscar.  I think Stalone must have realized the stellar performance that Rourke gave in that one 3 or 4 minute part and was glad he was cast for that role.The great thing about the DVD is that you get to see the out-takes.  They were very funny. Things like an actors cell phone ringing in the middle of a scene... Or Jet Li trying to get his english words right... Just hysterical stuff.  Get the DVD.  The out-takes alone are worth the price.

reviewText: If you are a man of a certain age, you are familiar with the work of the A-list 80s action stars - Schwarzenegger, Stallone and Willis.  It was very cool to see them all in one scene together.  You are also familiar with the B-list action stars and the Z-list action movies of the 80s.  Heck, I've seen Cannon Films messterpieces in the theater!  Those movies were simple, didn't require you to think too much, had a few cool set-pieces and one-liners, and gave you something cool to talk to your friends about the next day."The Expendables" is just that kind of 80s action movie.  The plot is simple, the characters are larger-than-life, and the movie doesn't worry a lot about backstory or plausibility.  We're thrust into the world of the Expendables, and either you buy into it or you don't.  The script makes it easy for you to buy into it.  I really enjoyed seeing the huge group of 80s and 90s action stars (including Dolph Lundgren!) as well.  These guys are experienced actors and really know what they're doing in a movie like this.  Part of the genius of keeping it simple is giving these actors a chance to do what they do best in front of a pretty basic canvas.  Stallone, who is consistently better at writing and directing than he gets credit for, brings his A-game to this film.The one thing I didn't care for was the intrusion of 21st century shakycam and quick edit techniques.  I realize this movie didn't have a huge budget, and the actors are getting older, and these techniques are often used to reduce the need for precise fight choreography.  But, sometimes the viewer is left not quite understanding what's going on.  Along those lines, during the big boss fight at the end, you can't even tell which of our good guys is actually fighting him.Having said that, "The Expendables" is at least worth a rent if you like or are interested in 80s action films.  Recommended.

reviewText: The Expendables is good old-fashioned dumb fun in the style of 80's invincible, one-man-army action movies-- you know the kind: impossible odds, endless streams of bullets, useless enemy soldiers who can't shoot the broad side of a barn, and tons of stuff blowing up, whether it needs to or not. If you're here, you came to see the action sequences and the ensemble cast of your favorite action film veterans, not for the spaghetti-thin plot. Once again, the good guys have to rescue the girl. The names are forgettable and the story of a corrupt South/Central-American dictator is pretty much just an excuse for the great fight sequences, absurd shootouts, car chase, and other ridiculously over-the-top stunts and shenanigans. In one scene, for example, the bad guys get strafed from above by the Expendables' seaplane by Lee Christmas (Jason Statham) sitting in a exposed nose turret, then doused with gasoline and the entire dock gets set ablaze with a flare gun, accompanied by a requisite explosion.The cast includes some of today's hottest action stars (and some nearly forgotten ones of yesteryear), including Jason Statham (Crank, the Transporter), Jet Li, MMA fighter Randy Couture, WWF superstar Steve Austin, Mickey Rourke, as well as a cameo from Bruce Willis and Arnold. As a result of all this star power, character development suffers and most of the characters are not fleshed out. We get some back-story about knife-expert Christmas and retired Expendables tattooman Tool (Rourke), but most of the other characters get nothing to work with. I even had trouble remembering some of their names after the movie was over. There are also some very unfunny short jokes aimed at Jet Li's character, Yin Yang.Former NFL player Terry Crews (Everybody Hates Chris: The Complete Series,White Chicks), one of my favorite character actors, is always a pleasure to watch. Here, he is the AA-12 automatic shotgun wielding terror. He brings a shot of energy and comic presence to the film, even if it's for a very short moment: "You know, the enemy will always be terrified of noise. Especially shotguns. With this big boy spittin' out 250 rounds a minute, you tell me who's tolerating that." Even with so few lines, he manages to bring a smile to my face. This is the exception, however. Most of the dialog in this film is corny, forced, and delivered with awkward timing and the finesse of a sledgehammer. Dolf Lundgren and Sly Stallone are as unintelligible as ever, if not more. They haven't aged a day, thanks to the miracle of plastic surgery. Some of their dialog, I really had to strain to understand what they were trying to say, not that what they say matters because it's all terribly unimportant. The scene where Willis, Arnold and Stallone meet in a church is brutally stiff. I've seen better delivery from my pizza man. It really was painful to watch the clumsy exchange. Stone Cold Steve Austen is stone cold dead in this film, being nothing more than a big goon who beats people up. He has zero stage presence.This is mindless summer fun that's inconsequential and requires absolutely no expenditure of brain cells. I do take issue with the way many of the fight sequences are shot and edited, making it difficult to see the action. Jerky camera and fast cuts make it hard to follow what's going on, leaving me a bit disoriented. Other than that and the already mentioned lack of character depth, this movie was entertaining for what it is. It doesn't pretend it's something more than a guns-blazing summer action flick. As I often say for movies like this, leave your brain at the door and enjoy!

reviewText: There was a time when you could rely on a bad action film to at least supply you with action. "The Expendables," which is said to be an homage to the guy films of the 1980s and 1990s, doesn't give you action so much as a blur of images chopped together so badly, you can barely revel in the violence they're meant to depict. What's the point in creating scene after scene of shootings and stabbings and explosions when the camera doesn't linger long enough on the aftermath? Why take the time for stunt training when every punch, kick, and jab is at the mercy of lightning-quick cuts, each leading to all manner of odd angles that don't really reveal the brutal maneuvering? Did director/co-writer Sylvester Stallone think the screenplay was ready to be shot? Even if it was ready, did Stallone actually believe the finished film was the best it could possibly be?"The Expendables" is loud, violent, and frenetic, qualities I might have gotten into had the stunts been edited in such a way that I could actually watch them. I wasn't seeing action choreography so much as a jumble of brutality and bloodshed. It seemed mangled, twisted, and deformed, like a fighters using his bare hands to punch solid brick walls. It's not a question of meaning or theme or symbolism; I didn't go into this movie expecting anything of the sort. What I did expect was to have fun, to be entertained by senseless yet well-photographed violent acts. Isn't that what action films are supposed to do?But wait, I haven't even gotten to the story yet. That's because there really isn't one to speak of. At least, not one that could be considered important or even comprehensible. So far, I've established that there's no good action to gawk at, nor is there a plot that can reasonably be followed. So what do I have left? The dialogue? Sadly, no; at times, it's so awkward that it seems to have been borrowed from another screenplay altogether. What am I supposed to make of a moment early in the film when the title characters square off with a band of Somalian pirates, only for Jason Statham's cell phone to start buzzing? Not only is this painfully unfunny, it doesn't match the tone the scene had been setting up. The last thing this movie needs is a sense of humor. Give us all the blood and bullets and stabbings you want, but for the love of God, don't try to get yourself off the hook by telling a joke.The plot, as it were, centers on a group of mercenaries led by Barney Ross (Stallone). The other members of his team are given irredeemably dumb names, such as Lee Christmas (Statham), Yin Yang (Jet Li), Gunnar Jensen (Dolph Lundgren), Hale Caesar (Terry Crews) and Toll Road (Randy Couture). They all have their areas of expertise. After the situation off the coast of Aden very nearly goes awry, it's decided that Gunnar - who just happens to be a sniper - needs to be kicked out, for it seems he's too emotionally unstable to continue being an Expendable. He leaves, dejected, determined to show Barney that his decision was the wrong one to make.In due time, Barney and his team are recruited by the secretive Mr. Church (a cameo by Bruce Willis) to enter a fictional South American country and overthrow a ruthless dictator. During this recruitment scene, we're treated to a cameo appearance by Arnold Schwarzenegger, although it seems kind of strange, what with him being the Governor of California and all. This, coupled with his character's long-standing rivalry with Barney, allows for the film's one genuinely funny line of dialogue: As he exits the scene, Barney turns to Mr. Church and says, "He wants to be president."Back to the plot. In this fake South American country, called Vilena, Barney is driven to do right by their contact, a young woman named Sandra (Gisele Itié), although it's for reasons I don't think I should reveal. Barney and his team also learn that the targeted dictator, General Garza (David Zayas), is actually under the thumb of an ex-CIA agent named James Munroe (Eric Roberts), one of those wickedly evil caricatures that always has to say something witty before, say, shooting someone. Any connection to James Monroe, the fifth President of the United States? What about his 1823 introduction of the Monroe Doctrine, which stated that Americans would no longer meddle in the affairs of foreign countries, specifically in Europe? Never mind.At Munroe's side are Wickham (Gary Daniels) - who's a toff one, he is - and Paine (Steve Austin), a gigantic brute of a henchman. They serve no real purpose other than doing all the physical things Munroe is unwilling to do.Rounding out the cast is Mickey Rourke as Barney's mission coordinator, Tool, a pipe-smoking tattoo artist. He represents the film's sole engaging character, and he supplies us with one scene of such incredible emotion, dialogue, and depth, I'm tempted to suggest that it wasn't written by Stallone. How could it have been when the rest of the film was relentlessly brutal? I suspect "The Expendables" will please fans of manly-man action, although they would have to be willing to get past the horrendous editing, which doesn't do much to reveal the glorious bloodshed. Perhaps Stallone's real goal was to reunite with Dolph Lundgren and give Mickey Rourke and Eric Roberts an excuse to once again be in the same film (unlike "The Pope of Greenwich Village," however, they share absolutely no screen time). I can't say I wouldn't have done the same thing. Then again, I wouldn't have skimped on the screenplay, either.
summary: Who Edits These Action Films, Anyway?

reviewText: There's something astonishing about poor reviews of this film, as if it was supposed to be something it's never promised to be in the first place. Even if you already know the premise, all you have to do is ask yourself one staggeringly easy question:Do you want to see Sylvester Stallone, Jason Statham, Jet Li, and Dolph Lundgren in the same fighting scene?If yes: Awesome, you have nothing to worry about, and don't even bother with what anyone else says. I typically see two sides to every argument, but in this case, they're wrong. There is no room for debate. If no: What the hell else could you want from a film that appeals exclusively to an audience that wants to see that? What are you even thinking? What else could you possibly expect even from looking at the damned posters?Films with very specific purposes like these are something neither critics nor users can seem to figure out. They've never been able to get it, and seem to run under this assumption that the film should be "more" than what it's ever said it would be. This is the exact equivalent of going to watch Commando and going "This is stupid." No, no it isn't, you're just stupid for thinking it was ever going to be anything else, idiot. You already know what the film is. The only thing you really have cause to worry about is if any of the actors present get particularly shafted and aren't even central to the film (see: Many other action films that promised this and just didn't do it, constructing the trailers literally out of the only footage they know people will pay to see), and that isn't a problem here. Everyone's got their place, and it all works out like you *should* freaking expect.If you didn't like this movie, you were never supposed to like it in the first place. The film never promised you a rose garden, for a tongue-in-cheek literature joke. If you don't even get that joke, then you should never review anything, ever again, because you don't even know what you like or why you like it.
summary: For some reason, people can't figure this film out. It's very simple.

reviewText: THE EXPENDABLESSTARRING: Sylvester Stallone, Jason Statham, Jet Li, Mickey Rourke, Dolph Lundgren, Randy Couture, Steve Austin, Terry Crews, Eric Roberts, Bruce Willis and Arnold SchwarzeneggerWRITTEN BY: Sylvester StalloneDIRECTED BY: Sylvester Stallone and Dave CallahamRated: RGenre: ActionRelease Date: 13 August 2010Review Date: 21 September 2010I know I'm gonna confuse a lot of you with this one. What expectations could I have had of this film? Well, believe it or not, mine were pretty high. I know it's supposed to be a bunch of old dudes kicking butt and taking names, but unfortunately that just wasn't enough for me. Not when I've come to admire Sylvester Stallone as a filmmaker, the way I have.Stallone not only stars in The Expendables, but wrote and directed it as well; as he did his two previous films, Rambo and Rocky Balboa.  But those were far superior to this chunk of a mediocre mess. I'm all for action and killing, and had it not been a Stallone film, I may not have had any reservations at all. But it was a Stallone film and I know Stallone has a much better film in him.Where was the creativity and wit that we found in Rocky Balboa and Rambo? With the exception of a few laughs, the majority of the dialogue here was cheesy and badly written. Lame one-liner after another. And the cinematography wasn't great either. Shots are often filmed way too close and don't flow well with one another, a lot of times throwing the comedic timing off in scenes.Stallone stars as Barney Ross; the leader of a group of mercenaries known as `The Expendables'; and that's all we know about him or them; begin senseless killing! Who are they? Where did they come from? The movie doesn't care. Stallone is a master at hand crafting brilliantly thought-out characters like Rambo and Rocky. He was nominated for an Academy Award for writing the character of Rocky so superbly! So what the hell happened here?The one character in the film I did find some substance in was Mickey Rourke's character `Tool'. Rourke played him as good as we've seen him play any number of roles, and as was the case in Iron Man 2; I wish there were more Rourke. Tool comes into the story to finish up a gnarly tattoo on Barney's back. Before we can ask why it was never finished, he is done in a matter of maybe five seconds, and now we are really wondering what the hell could have possibly happened, to cause them to be unable to finish the tattoo. Anyway, Tool tells Barney a tale of his haunted past, that formed the only scene in the film with a heartbeat.Tool's dark secret drives Barney to embark on a hell-bent rage to save a girl, being held captive by a league of scum-bags powered by the movie's villain (Eric Roberts). But why? Why does Barney care about this girl? They spent maybe 8 seconds together and there is no depth to her character or his, let alone some sort of bond that they could have shared that would warrant such heroic behavior in the first place. Simply put, Tool's words send Barney on his quest. Okay, whatever. So we follow him and he is joined by his pals who include performances by Jason Statham, Jet Li, Randy Couture and Terry Crews; together making up `The Expendables.'It's an absolute bloodbath when they get there, and I do have to say that Stallone does at least get the action right. Very balls to the wall, and a ton of fun. The best action sequences in a long time, for sure. And God bless him on an awesome idea to throw all these studs into one big action flick; especially the cameos by Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger.In short, the movie is like eating a big bag of cotton candy for dinner. It seems like a blast, and it's very tasty indeed; but you have a stomachache after.

reviewText: All of the trailers and TV spots have given people the idea that The Expendables  unites as many of the biggest action film stars in one film and promises to be one of the bloodiest and explosive films in recent memory. So to expect strong writing or a coherent story in a film like this would just be absurd, so I thought that expecting an entertaining action film and nothing more would fit the mold perfectly. Somehow the film still managed to be an out of control mess.The writing was cringe-worthy. It felt like we were thrown into a film that had already established a back story, but maybe that's what they were going for since most of these actors have action films that they're associated with. The dialogue will probably make you groan at how corny it is at times. If Mickey Rourke's speech about putting a Charlotte's Web tattoo on Jason Statham's "perfect, round head" wasn't improvised, then that is really disappointing as Rourke seemed to struggle on spitting the words out during that scene. The Expendables certainly felt like it filmed all the big action sequences first and then tried to throw together a script and a story at the last minute. One of the most humorous aspects of the film was the fact that it had to make a big deal about Steve Austin's character not having any objections to roughing up women when he was accused of abusing them in real life.With this many stars in the film, you can probably guess that it isn't very well balanced. Getting all of these action stars in one film is certainly an achievement, but most of them don't have much screen time. The first half of the film seems to be very Jason Statham heavy while the rest of the film is mostly Stallone. Jet Li and Mickey Rourke have a few scenes where they stick out while Dolph Lundgren seems to sit on the sidelines for most of the film. If you're going into this film expecting a larger role from someone who isn't in this paragraph, then you'll probably be disappointed due to how small their role really is.The film is capable of delivering some bone-crunching and blood soaked fight sequences in addition to an incredible amount of explosions that would even make Michael Bay contemplate whether or not he's had this much destruction in one film. Some of the ways that people die in the film are gloriously gruesome while the film shines brightest during the scenes where Barney's team is too busy fighting to say much of anything. Most of the action scenes in Vilena, the car chase that ends with the fight between Jet Li and Dolph Lundgren, and the finale of the film are all deliciously explosive, fast paced, and hit hard enough to satisfy most action film fans.The Expendables is poorly written and rather brainless, but is capable of giving its audience exactly what it advertised and that's deliver one of the loudest action films ever that features quite possibly the greatest gathering of action stars in any film. If you're somehow able to ignore the disconnected storyline and stupefyingly simple dialogue, then you'll probably be able to enjoy the clutter of explosive and fast paced action.
summary: A dud that packs a punch, but doesn't fully explode.

reviewText: I wanted to like this movie, I really do. reviewText: Let's face it: THE EXPENDABLES is not a great film.  It'll never win an award, never be regarded as a classic.  Nor should it be.  THE EXPENDABLES is an in-your-face action film, an homage to the great films of the 80s and early 90s starring Sly Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Bruce Willis, Dolph Lundgren, Jean-Claude Van Damme, Stephen Segal, and other butt-kickers.  If you like those films, you'll like this one; if you don't like those films, then stay away.As a trip down memory lane, as a rock-em-sock-em-one-liner extravaganza, THE EXPENDABLES succeeds admirably.  The plot is predictably lame: a bunch of mercenaries decide to take on a dictatorship, especially after the group's leader meets the dictator's beautiful, feisty (and, naturally, anti-daddy) daughter.  Things become a little more complicated when it's discovered that the dictator is a CIA stooge, but that won't stop our tough guys.  They can withstand bullets, bombs, fire, the elements--they're the Expendables!And that's what you get.  Take it or leave it.  Sly Stallone is in fine form, believe it or not.  Jason Statham (a genuinely good actor when he isn't kicking butt and not taking names) adds a little weight as Sly's second-in-command.  Others along for the ride: Mickey Rourke, Jet Li, Dolph Lundgren, Terry Crewes, Randy Couture (who should NOT act, even in a so-bad-it's-good movie like this), Eric Roberts, and Steve Austin.  Stallone and Statham get the most screen time, which is good because they're arguably the most talented actors here (and certainly the most fleshed-out characters).  Would've liked to have seen more of Rourke (he's got more talent in one finger than most of this cast combined), but he has better things to do these days.But you don't care about acting or plot.  You want action-action-action, and a few one-liners, and some cool as hell knife tossing.  And you got it, baby.  THE EXPENDABLES delivers what you want in your action movie--no more, no less.*MINOR SPOILER ALERT AHEAD (though I'm wondering how anyone could not know about it by now.)You may be wondering about the scene between Stallone, Bruce Willis, and Arnold Schwarzenegger.  Well.  It's short, so don't be disappointed.  It's predictable.  It's trite.  But, yes, it's totally amazing.  Having our three great action icons onscreen at the same time (or, at least, in the same scene)...it's worth the rental price alone.
summary: Everything you want in a mindless action movie.

reviewText: Keeping this mini-epic limited to cliché warehouses and exotic islands, writer/director Sylvester Stallone keeps "The Expendables" lean, lite, and simple while masterfully juggling a giant ensemble cast of convincing middle aged tough guys. While the focus is primarily on the amusing macho banter between Stallone and Statham, everyone is cast to their strengths and at least gets one moment to do their thing and do it well.  In more limited roles, Rourke delivers a soulful rambling monologue like only he can while Bruce Willis drops a bunch of F bombs like only he can. As can be expected, Arnold's cameo is short but sweet.  Lundgren gets a surprising amount of screen time in a memorable but weird even for him performance while Roberts threatens to steal the movie as the arrogant wise cracking villain.Much like the story, the action is brutish and simple. Don't expect too many complex emotional twists or turns, just the bad guys being a-holes, and the heroes blowing them to pieces with large guns in retort. Of course Stallone uses every opportunity to pour on the gore, but it should be noted that while the violence is graphic it is not nearly as mean and nasty as the violence in his last Rambo outing; it's all in good fun this time out.  There are also plenty of well staged fight sequences cast to the strengths of the performers; Li and Lundgren work a smart kung fu fight, Statham beats up a gang of obnoxious punks, UFC star Raynd Couture breaks limbs with mixed marital arts holds, while the aging Stallone gets his "a$$ kicked."  Be warned...there are good looking women in small roles but no 80s throwback gratuitous nudity.  Perhaps there's always a sequel.-Dan. S of dangerdiablogik

reviewText: When I was a kid, heroes were larger than life. They still are today only with just one exception albeit a pretty significant one... in those days, Men were Men. They weren't pretty but they exuded their God-given male born testosterone with every ounce of testicular sweat dripping on celluloid. For a boy growing up in the 80's they were the male role-models and father figures that inspired impressionable pre-adolescent boys into shaping their adult manhoods. Those were the days of yore.The Expendables isn't a great film by any stretch of the imagination but it knows exactly what it is trying to be and doesn't pull any punches. It tries to be theThe Magnificent Sevenof the modern action movie but doesn't quite hit its mark. It's more like the Magnificent Four and a Half (Stallone, Statham, Lundgren, Austin, and Li). The rest of the ensemble more or less being, ahem... expendable. My friend and I once had a similar idea for a movie that would pit all of our favorite 80's action stars into one no-holds-barred-royal-rumble-of-epic-manliness which we appropriately called "Cajones" but that was back in the mid-90's when there was still a chance to see most of these larger-than-life-nut-swingers together onscreen in their prime. The fact that Stallone, now 64, can prove that he still has what it takes and show the younger generations how to make an action movie proper after two successful comebacks with his acclaimedRocky BalboaandRambois a testament that there is still not only a demand but a primal need for REAL movie star icons like Stallone that are legends who defy their generation and age.There is only one thing you need to know about the paint-by-numbers plot and that is this: These titans of manliness have all come here to chew bubble-gum and kick ass, and there is a whole lotta bubble-gum to go around. When the blood and guts start flying it makes Peckinpah look like Walt Disney. If that is the kind of movie you are expecting to see you won't be disappointed. Perhaps the biggest fault with The Expendables is that it never quite lives up to itself. Arnold Schwarzenegger's cameo feels like it was thrown in just for the sake of having the three biggest 80's action icons together at last onscreen for a Hard Rock Cafe Kodak moment. It just feels like 'The Guvinator' shows up to give his quick endorsement before going back to the office. Fortunately Sly has much better things to do these days than bankrupting the state of Culifornia. I was never particularly a fan of so-called "professional" wrestling for all of its phoniness so guys like Stone Cold Steve Austin never really appealed to me but I'll take him and UFC's Randy Couture any day over any so-called leading male action star in Hollywood today just on sheer testosterone levels alone. At least Mickey Rourke showed that not all of professional wrestling is fake with "The Wrestler" but "Iron Man 2" hardly qualifies him as a bona fide action-star, more like Harley Davidson without the Marlboro Man. One look at his fugly face and you can see that his days of "9 1/2 Weeks" with the ladies are long over. Jason Statham is apparently the most masculine male action star Hollywood currently has to offer up and that's not saying too much with a resume consisting of "Lock, Stock, and Two Smoking Barrels," "Crank" and "The Transporter" series but I guess baldness apparently qualifies him in the testosterone brigade along with Bruce Willis whose days of headlining as an action star were washed up with the last "Die Hard." The truly expendable were those 80's action icons who didn't quite make the cut like Chuck Norris who for whatever reason was unable to attend Sly's little shindig. As a kid I probably watched every action film that Chuck starred in like "The Octagon," "Good Guys Wear Black," "Lone Wolf McQuade" and "A Force of One." You can't think of the 80's without bringing up Chuck Norris, or the poseurs like Jean-Claude Van Damme or Steven Seagal, all of whom are conspicuously MIA. Apparently Van Dammage was offered a part but he thought the script should have catered to his ego as well as a bigger paycheck so Sly made his part "Expendable."The Expendables is a fun salute to the 80's and a throwback to the days when action films weren't trying to be politically correct and were all about blowing stuff up, flexing their muscles, delivering the one-liners, kicking ass and looking cool. To that end, The Expendables is a blast, but not a slam dunk. It's worth a matinee out of pure sake of nostalgia or a rental. If The Expendables accomplishes one thing it should be this: To send a message to the studios that there is a hunger for masculine male action icons who are on the endangered species list and to ensure their survival in the 21st century which has been corrupted by forgettable momma's boys and blood sucking vampires of the Twilight generation.
summary: The Magnificent Seven of the modern male action movie

reviewText: I love me some good ol' fashioned action. In recent years action movies have tried to incorporate pseudo-intelligent plots amidst all the glorious explosions. While there is nothing wrong with wanting a "smart" action movie, I tend to lean more towards action movies that are over-the-top, loud, and obvious. Some of my favorite action movies have plots that are so improbable and bombastic that it seems that they were written by 5 year old boys on a sugar high. But that's the charm of old-school action movies. The bad guys are really bad, and the good guys aren't afraid to crack a few skulls. I had been trying to fill my craving for silly action movies with artsy action flicks of recent years. The Bourne trilogy? Too much shaky cam. Super hero movies like Iron Man or X-men? While very good, they are not action movies through and through. Then The Expendables comes along. When I saw it in theaters, I tried really hard to love it. But the fact is that it was missing something that I couldn't quite put my finger on. The explosions and silly plot were there. Sylvester Stallone was there. Arnie was there. Hell, Bruce Willis was even in on the fun. But, damn it, I couldn't bring myself to love it. I really liked it, but I couldn't love it. reviewText: There are cinematic all-star gatherings which dazzle you with their sheer acting chops, and then there's THE EXPENDABLES. This movie won't convince a guy to sign up at the Lee Strasberg Theatre & Film Institute, but it might make him revisit his 1980s action film collection or at least suck in his gut a little tighter, flex his guns a little more. I'm kinda bummed that Chuck Norris, Seagal, and Van Damme aren't here, because it seems like just about every other action film star for the past twenty years shows his mug in this picture. You could almost smell the geriatric testosterone oozing from the screen.Cue the cameos. When a shady CIA spook (Bruce Willis) presents a mission that even Barney Ross's rival (Schwarzenegger) turns down, Ross (Stallone) snaps it up. Me, I wasn't clear on the mission's specificity, other than it takes place on some island nation called Velena, which has been overrun by a corrupt American (Eric Roberts) and his murderous cronies. There's a hot Latin honey (Giselle Itié) involved, and she catches Ross's droopy eyes, except that there's about eighty years' difference in age between the two. Not to be outdone, Ross's right hand man, Lee Christmas (Jason Statham), romances none other than Charisma Carpenter. Alas, Jet Li's character arc amounts to his always demanding more money. He's smaller, Jet contends, and so has to work harder and should get compensated more.Stallone directs and acts. Or directs, anyway. Look, what did you expect? Certainly not a nuanced storyline, I hope. This film is nuanced in the same way that Sly is glib with the tongue twister. What Stallone achieves best here is sort of like what Coach Phil Jackson does with his championship teams, which is manage the egos. Most of the burly dudes featured here are used to starring in their own flicks, so from the angle of massaging his cast, I thought Sly did a bang up job. Each actor gets his moment to shine and show off his wares. I was amazed at Sly's rapid reload scene. Dolph Lundgren once again channels his inner crazy to pretty good effect. Bullets fly with abandon. Things blow up. Brutal fighty fights erupt. Salonpas and Preparation H are generously applied. All according to Stallone's vision. This is a far cry from ROCKY, a lot closer to GET CARTER or ASSASSINS. There are some hardcore kill shots.But, again, it's not about the creaky story. It's all about this summit meeting of action stars, past and present, and their interactions, convivial and violent. I thought that Sly got on well with Statham and Mickey Rourke, and that's fine.  Mickey Rourke's scenes, by the way, come off like he just strolled in from a much better flick. Imagine if Clint Eastwood had been in this one? He would've slaughtered everyone with his acting presence and, literally, with his big .44 Magnum.I had big rapt eyes set on the various dust-ups, like Jet Li taking on Dolph Lundgren and, later, martial artist Gary Daniels (who starred in some actioners in his heyday). And a brawl pitting Randy "the Natural" Couture against "Stone Cold" Steve Austin, well, it could only end with a Superman punch. Apropos of nothing, Couture earns bonus points for later, in real life, taking on boxer James "Lights Out" Toney and forcing a submission out of him in the first round. One big beef I have is that Jet Li's character had to be saved at least twice by Stallone. That's just friggin' disrespectful to Jet, who in his prime could've probably wiped the floor with the cast. But, out of all of them, it's Jason Statham who comes out the most dynamic in the buttkicking department. Handsome Rob is in his physical prime, friends. Critics can knock low brow cinema all they want. Sometimes, folks just want to eyeball explosions and shoot-em-'ups and sheer undiluted machismo. Concerning THE EXPENDABLES, I hear there's a sequel in the works. So snobs can suck it. 3.5 out of 5 stars for this one.The single DVD's extra stuff: Sly Stallone's audio commentary; "Before the Battle" is the Making Of feature which goes out of its way to document Sly's various injuries incurred during the shooting of the film (00:15:38 minutes long); one deleted scene featuring Gunner (Lundgren) cracking a joke during the film's opening sequence (00:00:45); a gag reel (00:05:03); and the marketing archive (the theatrical trailer, TV spots, and a poster gallery).

reviewText: The secret to enjoying this testosterone-laden flick is to not take it too seriously. Don't look for any profound messages--there weren't supposed to be.The script was like a fusion of Megaforce and some of the paramilitary adventure fiction from the 1980s. You know--that decade when the big name actors in this cast (Stallone, Swarzenneger, Willis, Lundgren...) were lighting up the box office with huge Hollywood explosions. During a recon for some merc work in a Third World dictatorship, Sly Stallone and Jason Statham inadvertently befriend the altruistic daughter of the dictator before making a grand exit from the nation and basically saying (with actions-speak-louder-than-words panache), "take this job and shove it."But back stateside, Sly has an attack of conscience about leaving the fair damsel (Giselle Itié) at the mercy of the dastardly despot and his Evil Capitalist Puppetmaster. He's going back in to get her, doggone it, alone with no plan. But even Sly might have trouble taking on an entire nation by himself, so his merc buddies come along for the pyrotechnic ride. Jet Li, the most mercenary of these mercenaries, is the first to put friendship before money and commit to stick with his comrade come napalm or high pungis. Now you have an adequate excuse for a martial arts shoot-em-up Hollywood Fireball Fest, and director/star Stallone delivers, big-time.I was expecting it to be far more obvious tongue-in-cheek parody of the genre, but they took a slightly more marketable route, ensuring it's not SO stupid that young adults wouldn't like it. But it's got just enough stupidity, delivered with such finesse, that I had a grand ol' time and laughed out loud on several occasions.The martial arts segments would have been much more pleasing without all the avant garde camera work, and I could have done without all the close-ups on Stallone's jewelry. But there was a little bit of everything for action flick buffs: A smorgasbord of cinematic fight scene superstars who all get some thumping time; a car chase in which a beautiful old fat-fender stepside hot rod pickup gets shot and smashed to pieces; more exploding ordinance than the Falklands campaign; and some gratuitous gore that is either horrific or hilarious, depending on your mood and personality disorder.Once upon a time, I fantasized about making a mindless action flick with a cast like this...but when they were all a little shorter in the tooth. Along with Sly, Arnie and Dolph I would have cast Norris, Bronson, Eastwood, Van Damme, Ventura, Carl Weathers, Fred Williamson and Jim Brown. Can you imagine the mayhem and blood-curdling dialog? If my time machine could go back far enough, I'd draft Lee marvin and Robert Mitchum, too.This isn't The Dogs of War, nor is it Commando. It's not completely sober, but it doesn't descend into campiness, either. What it can be, if you kick the girls and snobs out of the Man Cave for a couple hours, is a lot of fun.Henry Brown is the author of TEOTWAWKI aviation adventure The Delayed Blitz(Krieg), as well as the military thriller Hell and Gone. He is the columns editor at New Pulp Fiction, and does some blogging of his own at the Two-Fisted Blogger.

I enjoyed the way those two played off of each other and hinted at a few of their other movies in the dialogue but it wasn't enough to really make me smile. Most of the time I felt as though the movie was saying, "Look! We got all these cool actions stars! Isn't that neat?!" as if that was enough to make me forget how awful the movie was.Movies like this seem to forget that we need to care about the characters first and then they can take us on a ride. We as audiences can forgive an awful lot if we care about the characters. For instance I wanted to care when Statham's character was so distraught over his girlfriend dumping him that he can't throw his trademark knives straight but honestly all I could think was "who are these people?!". These are set pieces, not characters. They are defined by their weapons and visual traits. You've got the "Big Black Guy with a Big Gun", the "Asian Guy who knows kung-fu" the "Giant Guy", the "Knife Guy", the "Tattoo Guy". For villains you've got the "Evil White Guy in a Suit", the "Generic Hispanic Dictator/General". There is even a "Damsel in Distress" who we never really feel is in distress but rather, patiently waiting for the end of her scenes.A word on editing styles. I know it has become popular to mimic the "shaky cam" action sequences in the "Bourne" movies but it must be done well to succeed. In "Bourne" the camera may have been shaky but we still had a sense of timing and flow. We felt every hit, cringed at every injury. In Expendables what you get is so many cuts to so many different angles in such rapid succession that your eyes get tired and your mind wanders. You start thinking random thoughts like, "I wonder what my cholesterol is?" "I should be doing laundry today" "I wonder if Guinea pigs make good pets?"Now the CG. If you can tell, instantly, that every knife that one character throws is CG, then you need to re-animate those scenes. There was not one believable piece of Cg in this entire movie. To give an idea of quality think made for SyFy network Sunday afternoon monster movie.In all, this was a disappointing sleepwalk through nonsense and clichés. reviewText: With the age of giant, muscle bound heroes generally past us, it's refreshing to see a movie that hearkens back to the 80's and early 90's, when the giants of Schwarzenegger, Stallone, Willis, and others took on the bad guys with cheesy one liners.  And while "The Expendables" won't resurrect the muscle hero genre, it is a nice, charming visit that's a lot of fun to go along with.The plot of "The Expendables" is very simple.  Sylvester Stallone is the head of a group of mercenaries who will do any job for any price.  When a job comes in to take out some shadowy figures in charge of an enslaved banana republic, his team go in to do their job while Stallone has a more personal stake in what's going on.It's a very simple plot, but in a movie like this, that's all it needs, as well as simple characters.  You won't get any in-depth studies of the human psyche, as the characters are labeled by a defining trait.  Stallone is the leader, another guy is hotheaded and loves knives, another guy loves his automatic shotgun, another is the short Asian guy who gets picked on, and another guy has ears that look like Cauliflowers.  But it works, as the characters are larger then life, and don't need any real character development at all.  Such a thing is also secondary to the numerous fights, explosions, gunfire, and one liners thrown our way every few minutes, or, in the case of the finale, every few seconds.If you're a fan of giant, hot-blooded action movies, then "The Expendables" is definitely worth a look.  It's perfectly content to be big, loud, and full of giant muscles.  But it works, and it's fun.  It a fine tribute to the action films as old...and as an added bonus, we get a great scene where Arnold Schwarzenegger, Stallone, and Bruce Willis all appear together in the same scene for the very first time.  It's short, but a fun reminder that some of the most memorable action heroes in film history are truly larger then life, and only need to rely on their charisma to carry a film, and that's celebrated all the way through "The Expendables."
summary: A fun, charming throwback to the action days of old

reviewText: I know I'm coming to this party a little late, but I can't leave it alone.  Last night, I finally saw The Expendables.  Part of me wanted to see this movie when it was released in theaters last year, but the bad reviews discouraged me.  Recently the film was made available on Netflix, so I thought I'd give it a tumble.It's not like I had high hopes.  Directed by Sylvester Stallone, the movie stars Jason Statham, Jet Li, Mickey Rourke, Dolph Lundgren, Terry Crews, Steve Austin, Randy Couture, and of course, Stallone himself.  The film also features cameos by Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger.  Hardly an ensemble cast of accomplished thespians, so I went into the film with especially low expectations.Somehow the The Expendables managed to exceed them.  There are simply no words to describe how bad this movie is.  I already mentioned the cast, but surprisingly, despite the presence of former UFC and WWE stars bringing down the curve, the acting really isn't the problem, or at least, not the most obvious.  The real problem is one of the worst scripts in the history of cinema.  It's written by David Callahan (?), whose most significant previous work is the screenplay for Doom. Watching this movie,  you'd think Stallone bought the story from the 3rd place finisher in a middle school writing contest for $20 and a signed copy of Tango and Cash.It's essentially a plot held together by a series of one-liners.  Bad ones.  Like, so bad you don't even understand them.  Now you might say, as defenders of the film do, the movie is a throwback, an homage to 80s action films that weren't very good themselves.Balderdash.Yes, many of those 80s movies that we love weren't all that great, but they at least had some style and panache.  Movies like Roadhouse and Commando are on the Mount Rushmore of over the top, 80s cinema excesses, but they were fun and unabashedly committed to style over substance.  Eighties action movies are legendary for their one-liners, but the story wasn't built around them.  Some were cheesy ("I feel the need, the need for speed!"), some were ridiculous ("Let off some steam Bennett!"), but they always made you smile ("I'm too old for this $#!%.").  And when they were delivered, there was no conceit, no inside joke, no shame.  Just perfect timing ("Yippee-ki-yay @#$%&!").Not so here.  Expendables isn't fun.  It's boring and incomprehensible.  From what I could figure out, Stallone and co. are a group of mercenaries who are hired by the CIA to kill a "rogue" agent who is taking over some small, nameless South American country in order to start his own drug trade.  But during a recon mission, he is captivated by young woman who refuses to leave when given the chance, choosing to stay and help her people.  Stallone decides he must go back to rescue her.  And of course, his fellow mercs (all four of them) sympathize and decide to join their friend in taking on an entire army by themselves for free.  Not surprisingly, they succeed (with no casualties).The action isn't bad; well choreographed and fast.  The violence quotient is pretty high with bones and joints being broken and bent the wrong way.  Bodies are shredded and blown apart by weapons fire.  But it comes at you so fast, it begins to blur together. None of the action is in the least bit compelling because you don't really believe any of the heroes are in danger, or care enough about them if they were.As far as the characters, the only thing that differentiates them is how they prefer to kill people.  Stallone's the crack shot.  Statham is the knife guy.  Jet Li's the martial arts expert.  Crews is the heavy weapons guy and so on.  The acting, like I said before, is about what you'd expect given the screenplay they had to work with, but one guy stands out below the rest.  I don't remember Dolph Lundgren being a particularly bad actor, but his "performance" makes you think a drunk wandered onto the movie set, stumbling and slurring his way around, demanding that he be given a part.  I seriously couldn't understand a word he said.It's too bad.  With its cast, the film had the potential to be a lot of fun.  Stallone has shown he can direct halfway decent films.  His last two outings, Rocky Balboa and Rambo were actually kind of compelling.  The Expendables, in contrast, is dull, humorless, and I found myself checking my watch hoping it would end soon.  The worst part, however, is that no one, not my friends, not my family told me how bad this movie is.  Shame on them.
summary: Ever step in a pile of crap?

reviewText: Lofty expectations are rarely met.  The Expendables is one of those unusual occasions in which expectations are not only met, but they are exceeded.  This is pantheon level action, a truly guy's guy movie, a knock-down drag-out, butt kicking, action extravaganza that pays homage to the awesome battles and ridiculous body counts of 80s action flicks.  There has been a dearth of traditional action films and heroes over the past two decades, but the old guys get together with some new blood to retake the title.Speaking of the awesome battles, they are split into four definite specialties: guns, fighting, knives, explosions.  Last first, the explosions are incredible.  Absolutely everything blows up; it's as if gas lines ran throughout every set piece on the film.  Half way through the movie I began to visualize mighty pillars of the villain's estate as massive sticks of dynamite.  The knife throwing is thankfully more than a novelty, as roughly 20 enemies on the Caribbean island of Vilena get gutted, beheaded, and/or eviscerated.  With this cast, battles are guaranteed.  Well, it's MUCH more than expected, much more realistic than anticipated, so real that Stallone had to have emergency surgery on his back after Austin throws him into a brick wall (you'll know the scene when you see it).  Last but not least, the gun-play.  Put simply, this is a Waco stock-piling, NRA wet dream.  Thousands of bullets carve bodies apart like Commando on steroids.  No less than five times did I lean forward, wide-eyed saying "F*** yeah!"  Turn the action up to eleven, folks.  If you don't like this movie, check your pulse.The ensemble cast is everything you'd expect.  Stallone leads a group of mercenaries consisting of Jet Li, Terry Crews, Randy Couture, Dolph Lundgren, and Jason Statham who are hired by an undercover CIA agent (Bruce Willis) to ostensibly remove a dictator/general and his rogue CIA agent funding.  Throw a beautiful woman who needs saving into the mix and you have enough plot, and enough reason, to fly a jet into a small port town and spray down twenty or so soldiers before lighting another couple dozen on fire with jet fuel...for starters.Go into this tabula rasa, looking for minimal plot and sub-par dialogue.  Who cares?  Negotiate with hollow point is what I say.  Compromise with C4.  Adrenaline from beginning to end.  Expect John Matrix to kill without discretion, Rocky to battle Ivan Drago, Jet Li to kick everyone within roundhouse radius, Randy Couture and Stone Cold Steve Austin to dish out body slams like herpes, Jason Statham to trump his own Transporter movies, Terry Crews to blow everything up (p-p-p-p-p-p-power!), and just appreciate that Arnold and Willis are on board for the cameo, the camaraderie, and the yippee-ki-yay...(you know the rest)!!  It's that good.Honestly, this is the best action movie I've seen in twenty years.  I could write a 50-page thesis on various subtleties I enjoyed.  The only negatives are the absence of Steven Seagal and Jean Claude Van Damme (both were offered parts), and some of the action was too choppy (think thirty straight one-second bursts).  Both easily overlooked.  However, unless you go in expecting Citizen Kane (if you do, it's your fault), this epic crowd pleaser should leave you cheering.

reviewText: Of course, out of solidarity for the action fan you were in the eighties, you need to buy this upcoming DVD. It's for the Macho or the caveman inside all of us. Testosterone at it's best. A tribute like that won't be made often. No matter how trivial the story, no matter how corny the dialogue, you will want this in your collection. There is an obvious pleasure in seeing Arnold, Sly and Bruce together, even if it is for a short period of time. I did feel sad about the way Arnie and Sly looked, though. Clint Eastwood ages well, I think. When Charles Bronson was alive, he still looked tough, even in his seventies. But Arnold and Sly? Something in the way they walked... The eyes are still piercing but the Austrian oak looked... dismembered and the Italian Stallion seemed to be limping or something.Anyhow. We all knew before hand that the screenplay wouldn't win an Oscar. But why do people seem content with that? I wrote at the beginning that the only fact of having that many action stars in one single movie is sufficient but still, it didn't have to be this way. Look at "The Losers" for example. It's a similar story. And it is overblown, absurd and exaggerated just like "The Expendables". But with the first, you're ready to accept pretty much anything. It's based on a comic book and doesn't take itself seriously whereas the second, Stallone movie that is, is soooo solemn even if it tries to have fun at times. That's a Stallone thing. He jokes about himself and he does make us laugh at times. But the solemnity, I think, lessens its wackiness.But I have to admit that there are some guilty pleasures in the movie. After the viewing, you will be glad to talk about the way Stone Cold opened up a can of whoop-ass and layed the smack down on Sly's butt. You'll still laugh about how Jason Statham stole the movie at two specific places or how Terry Crews wipes out an entire battalion within a few seconds. They are some good ideas that forces a grin on your face (Jet Li wanting a raise because he is shorter, Statham saying to his ex-girlfriend, after a impressive fight, that he was worth it, Lundgren saying "my turn!" when he fights Li, the little jabs Arnold and Sly throw at each other, Couture talking about his ears, etc...).The only problem, really, is the misguided importance it tries to instill. Oh! And also, those darn camera movements (too fast and too much twirls) that, again, give the impression that Stallone really wanted to give a personal signature to something that should have been taken way more lightly.Hope he corrects this for the sequel. reviewText: In "The Expendables," that which gets the most screen time, has the most facial expressions, and is clearly the best actor is a seaplane with "Global Wildlife Conservancy" painted on it. reviewText: "The Expendables" comes at you with barrels a-loaded and guns a-blazin' right from scene one!  Many reviews on here are saying this is a throwback or a tribute to 80's action flicks.  While I cannot disagree completely, I can say that it isn't relegated to that distinction only. It is just as much a part of today's action movie scene as it is to the 80's scene.Let me start by saying that I have a wife who isn't overly fond of Stallone, Schwarzenegger, and the like. On the night we went to the movies, we decided to see two of them, one of my choice and one of hers. My choice, of course, was "The Expendables." She made sure she told me on the way to the theater, "I really don't want to watch "The Expendables."""It's only fair," I replied with a gleam in my eye and anticipation coursing through my veins.So after it was over and we exited the theater, I was a bit reluctant to ask her what she thought. I assumed that I already knew her answer, and frankly, I didn't want to hear what my discerning mind already was certain it was going to hear. But being a glutton for the occasional wife-induced punishment, I asked anyway. I about fell over when she replied with, "It was real good...waaaayyyy better than I thought it was going to be.""Huh?" I replied, dumbfounded. I'm sure I looked like a deer in the headlights."It was good," she assured me with a smile. After that we marched into another theater to watch Round 2 of movie night, her choice, "Nanny McPhee Returns," which was actually quite good, as well, I might add, especially since we had the ENTIRE theater to ourselves...not a soul was in there besides us two. Later on that night, she made the comment, "We got to see two excellent movies."WOW! I was floored. "Good" had now been escalated to "Excellent!"It really doesn't matter that the younger generation is having problems with older guys performing in action flicks. Granted, Stallone has a few wrinkles, and he's a little rough around the edges, but he's still built like a Mack truck and as tough as an overcooked prime rib steak. His talents are endless, and he deserves to be admired for his accomplishments. Now you can add "The Expendables" to that long list. It was an exceptionally fun movie, and I recommend it to everyone who likes a good action film with good actors having fun while doing it.A+!One more thing worth noting. It's quite refreshing to know, and maybe younger generation Hollywood should take the hint, that you don't need to drop F-Bombs every four seconds to make an outstanding movie. reviewText: What do you get when you join together some of the biggest action stars from the last three decades into one single movie? Well, in this particular instance, you get a testosterone-fueled, orgy of mayhem and destruction that is unrelentingly violent and undeniably exciting from start to finish. You get "The Expendables"."The Expendables" follows the exploits of a group of guns for hire who are tasked with the job of overthrowing a cruel dictator. However, the mission becomes complicated by the fact that not everything is what it seems and betrayal seems to be the name of the game. To survive, the team must use every skill and weapon at their disposal and even then, that may not be enough to win the day.I never would have thought that bringing together virtually every action star imaginable into one bombastic action extravaganza would work. I figured with so many egos and that much testosterone in one place, the movie would be nothing more than an obnoxiously noisy cacophony of explosions and gunfire with zero logic or cohesion behind it all. Yet, somehow director, co-writer and star Sylvester Stallone managed to make everyone play nice (so to speak) all the while creating a solid and engaging action movie in the process.The story for this film, written by Dave Callaham ("Doom") and Sylvester Stallone is by no means filled with rich character development, drama, or an intricately conceived plot. Of course, for this type of film no one is really expecting Oscar caliber material in any capacity. Essentially, the story does just a little more than set up the next action sequence, but that's alright with me (in this rare instance). Because, if I wanted something more thought provoking or potentially enriching then I would have chosen a drama to begin with, and most likely Stallone and company would have been nowhere in sight.I know that my being ok with a movie's story being nothing more than the glue holding a string of fight scenes together may seem a bit inconsistent. After all, this is typically the sort of thing that irritates me with so many action movies these days. The difference between "The Expendables" and all the others is that there's something enjoyable and entertaining about the movie besides the non-stop action. What it boils down to is this, what little story there is to be found is interesting enough to keep my attention; whereas, in so many of its contemporaries the bits of story tend to feel tedious and/or boring.Speaking of action movies, it is becoming increasingly clear that Stallone has a very solid grasp on how not to make an action-centric movie feel stale or unexciting. First with "Rambo" and now "The Expendables", Sly knows how to give the audience just enough tidbits of story sprinkled between the action to keep the movie flowing, while at the same time never losing the momentum that the exciting action scenes are creating.One of his choices, as both co-writer and director of this movie, which I really appreciated, was that he allowed each of his veteran action stars a moment to shine. Be they hero or villain, each and every one of them was allotted their fair share of the violent-driven spotlight.Speaking of the stars, this assemblage of action heroes and villains proved that even though some of them may be a little long in the tooth, they've still got what it takes to kick some serious butt when the occasion arises. Now as far as acting goes, none of the stars really delivered anything note worthy in their performances. But, as I stated earlier, no one really expected Oscar caliber out of this film. All anyone wants to see out of the stars of this movie is them kicking butt and taking names. So long as they can still do that, then the audience will go home satisfied.Also, within the movie's cast there were several cameos that serve as potential teasers for the inevitable sequel. For starters Bruce Willis ("RED") and Arnold Schwarzenegger ("Terminator: Salvation") both appeared in the same scene and threw several zingers each others way, all the while teasing at a history between themselves and Stallone's character, Barney which could prove interesting to explore.Then there's Mickey Rourke ("Iron Man 2") as the tattoo artist and "agent", as it were, for Stallone's crew. Throughout his multi-scene appearance there are comments regarding the former mercenary life of Mickey's character, and there are glimpses of that man in a couple of scenes late in the film. Basically giving us enough information to garner interest, but not reveal too much so as to spoil future installments.Perhaps, in the future we'll get to see more of what was teased to us during these cameos in the film. If so, then the sequels could prove to be just as entertaining, if not more so than the original. One thing is for certain, the appearances were fun little moments for fans of the action genre, and provided some intriguing character history for the franchise to explore later on.Overall, "The Expendables" is an extremely fast-moving, hard-hitting action packed thrill ride that features an abundance of Hollywood's action stars and should easily satisfy even the most hardcore of action junkies."The Expendables" is rated R for violence and language.

reviewText: The 114 minute extended director's cut of Sylvester Stallone's 2010 action extravaganza "The Expendables" is a more deep, well rounded and satisfying version of the film that was already a great deal of fun in its original 103 minute theatrical cut. I'm usually wary of so called "extended" or "unrated" cuts of modern movies as they usually just involve shoehorning back in deleted scenes that were cut out for a reason.The director's cut of The Expendables isn't that at all. As Sly himself states in a great introduction to the new blu-ray of his film, he basically started from scratch and re-edited the movie from the ground up to what his original vision and intention of the film was from the outset. He says that he liked the theatrical cut  but that he loves the director's cut. I completely agree with him!One thing that really stuck out to me is that the theatrical cut was edited in such a way that the majority of the film seemed to be focused much more on Sly and Jason Statham's characters. That is completely understandable since they were really the box office draw (in addition to the Bruce Willis and Schwarzenegger cameos). One of the criticisms of the theatrical cut that a lot of people had was that the other members of the Expendables team weren't given as much room to breathe and seemed kind of short changed in terms of getting to know who they all were better.This has been completely rectified in the extended director's cut as all of the other characters get nice additional moments that really brings a sense of how they work as a team better than the theatrical cut did at times. The director's cut seems to have a lot more heart and soul now than it did in the theatrical cut. While I still prefer the theatrical cut of his 2008 film "Rambo" to the extended director's cut as I didn't agree with a lot of the additions that he put back in, I completely agree with his decisions on this new director's cut of The Expendables. So if you're a big fan of the film as I was, it's worth it picking it up as most places only have it for 15 dollars right now. None of the additions slow down the pacing of the film in my opinion and instead greatly enrich it. There's also more humor in this cut too that doesn't seem forced and makes the characters even more likeable.The one thing that I need to mention is that the excellent Stallone commentary track wasn't carried over to this release which makes sense as he did that one for the theatrical cut. He didn't though record a new commentary track for the director's cut as he's knee deep in making the sequel at the moment. The exhaustive Inferno documentary has been carried over but all of the other extras from the theatrical cut blu-ray like the post production featurette and the hilarious 2010 Comic-Con panel are missing in action. I particularly liked on the director's cut blu ray the 20 minute interview with Sly going over his career particularly as a director. I would just switch out the extended cut blu-ray with the pointless digital copy disc in the original 3 disc release and make your own sort of deluxe edition of The Expendables. If you haven't seen the film yet and are wanting to check it out, I recommend the director's cut over the theatrical cut as it is a better version of the film. I view this new release as much moreso complementing the original release rather than replacing it.Highly recommended and I can't wait for The Expendables 2 in August 2012! BRING ON THE EXPLOSIONS!!!
summary: Superior to the theatrical cut (but hold onto the 1st blu-ray).

reviewText: What THE EXPENDABLES boils down to is the Second Wave's version of "Boit an Koik" in TOUGH GUYS.  This is a manic romp through every Beer Film cliche ever created.Stallone taps his role in COBRA to find himself as the boss of "The Expendables" a bunch of hard-core mercenaries a la "The A-Team." This bunch, mostly without women, is a beer-drinking, hog-riding fraternity, dedicated to kicking @$$.  Jason Statham (CRANK), Jet Li and Mickey Rourke are the biggest names here. They are hired by the mysterious "Mr. Church" (Bruce Willis in a suit) to overthrow the corrupt Banana Republic President (David Zayas of DEXTER) of a fictional sort-of South American country. If this sounds a little like COMMANDO, with The Governator, no surprise. The Hon. Gov makes an uncredited appearance as a cranky competitor for the job. As Schwartzenegger bangs out, Willis asks Stallone, "What's his problem?" "He wants to be President," Stallone deadpans, just as Ahnold turns and smiles.I said, "mostly without women" and that's true, except for Statham's love interest who gets punched out by her boyfriend. Statham shortly thereafter disassembles the guy like a Lego set. Oh, and Stallone's crush, the daughter of the Puppet In A Hat President of the falling-apart country he's been hired to overthrow.The Expendables head down to the island, where they come ashore anything but quietly and start blowing everything up, obviously having read THE DOGS OF WAR for inspiration. After they end up torching everything that moves, including the American expat who runs the obligatory drug ring (LETHAL WEAPON, anyone?) they turn the country over to Stallone's squeeze and fly off drinking beer and singing.It's not a great film. It's not even a great beer film. For one thing, the cast takes themselves WAAAY too seriously. Where's Chuck Norris?Still, this is an homage, not a Johnny-Come-Lately Original, and it knows it. These guys are all long in the tooth. Fearless and void of emotion, he is the leader, the sage and the strategist of this tight-knit band of men who live on the fringe. His only attachment is to his pickup truck, his seaplane and his team of loyal modern-day warriors. His is a true cynic who describes what he does as 'removing those hard to get at stains'. The team behind him is made up of Lee Christmas, former SAS and a savant with anything that has a blade; Ying Yang, a master at close-quarter combat; Hale Caesar, who has known Barney for ten years and is a long-barrel weapons specialist; Toll Road, a skilled demolitions expert and considered the intellect of the group; and Gunner Jensen, a combat veteran and an expert in precision sniping who struggles with his own demons. When the mysterious Church offers Barney a job no one else would take, Barney and his team embark on what appears to be a routine mission: overthrow General Gaza, the murderous dictator of the small island country of Vilena and end the years of death and destruction inflicted on its people. On a reconnaissance mission to Vilena, Barney and Christmas meet their contact Sandra, a local freedom-fighter with a dark secret. They also come to learn who their true enemy is: rogue ex-CIA operative James Munroe and his henchman Paine. When things go terribly wrong, Barney and Christmas are forced to leave Sandra behind, essentially giving her a death sentence.
