reviewText: The Expendables is a moronic love letter to 1980s action movies, most of which weren't that great in the first place. While the '80s did produce a few action classics - Die Hard and The Terminator spring to mind - The Expendables is more in the vein of laughable junk like Commando. Indeed, with its by-the-numbers plot, cardboard characters, and lame action scenes, The Expendables pays tribute to the genre at its worst rather than its best.I'm surprised at Stallone, who is capable of thoughtful writing and direction ... whenever he works on Rocky movies. Somehow, when he steps out of Rocky's shoes, the IQ of his output drops about 70 points. The fact that more people saw The Expendables than Rocky Balboa - an infinitely worthier film - is depressing to me, in the extreme.Where do I start complaining about this film? Every scene, every character, and every line of dialog is a bad cliche. None of the characters is developed at all, beyond being given the most superficial traits (this guy is good at throwing knives ... this guy has a really loud gun). The first half hour of the film drags terribly, with no memorable action scenes; then the action starts, and it's all fast cutting, repetitive explosions, and terrible digital effects (including digital violence ... always dumb-looking). At one point, there's a shot of a building being destroyed that manages to look much faker than similar special effects in recent Godzilla films. Tsk, tsk.Needless to say, the film is politically incorrect in the extreme. The Expendables are apparently "liberating" an island from tyranny, but none of the islanders has any personality or significant screen time. The two female characters in the movie, meanwhile, have almost nothing to do; I think Charisma Carpenter of "Buffy" fame has about three lines of dialog in the whole movie. Was it really necessary to make the script so aggressively offensive?Lest I go overboard with the complaints, I will now cite one positive aspect of the film. Arnold Schwarzenegger's cameo rocks. In one brief scene, he manages to prove that he's a much more charismatic actor than Stallone (provided that Stallone isn't playing Rocky, that is).As for the DVD itself, the special features include: a making-of special (in case you want to know how nonsense like this ever gets made); a pointless deleted scene; a commentary in which Stallone says things like "explosions are unpredictable"; and a gag reel, the highlight of which involves Eric Roberts belching on camera. A worthily stupid package for this movie, then.In conclusion, I declare that all fans of this movie should be forced to watch good movies (e.g., When a Woman Ascends the Stairs; The Best of Youth) until they develop an appreciation for human drama that isn't unrelentingly awful. And if you must watch action movies, surely the aforementioned Die Hard is a better choice?
summary: They don't make 'em like this anymore ... thank goodness

reviewText: "The Expendables" is a merry cheerful genocide between old friends à la sauce testosterone, a very violent and in the same time surprisingly tender, nostalgic, full of humour and less than half serious movie - and I loved every minute of it!The story is in principle about a group of mercenaries, many of them a little bit aged, who are hired by the CIA to eliminate the military dictator ruling a little island in the Caribbean - but the plot is really really NOT important, and so it will not be discussed further.The team of mercenaries is small but lethal (of course!). Its leader Barney Ross is (of course!) played by Stallone himself, who also wrote the scenario and directed the film. Ross is the oldest member of the team; he is also a man of few words, without much personal life, very calm and slightly sad. His great pride is to be the fastest man to draw and shoot the gun - "Only light is faster"...The second in command, Lee Christmas, is played by Jason Statham, who gives an IMPRESSIVE performance!! Christmas is much younger than his commander (and best friend), much more extraverted and with a gorgeous, although unfaithful girlfriend played by Charisma Carpenter. He is an excellent marksman and an accomplished martial arts expert, but his personal specialty is knife fight and especially knife throwing. In homage to the "Magnificent seven" old western classic, Ross and Christmas have at every possible occasion a friendly speed competition between knife and revolver...The third most important member of the team is Gunner Jensen, a gigantic sociopathic and borderline insane sniper played with great brio by Dolph Lundgren - who gives in this movie his (in my modest opinion) best screen performance ever. Considering the fact that Lundgren almost killed (accidentally) Stallone when they turned "Rocky IV" (Sly spend eight days in ICU), their reunion is a particularly touching cinema moment.Number four is Ying Yang, played by Jet Li. Much shorter and smaller than his pals, Yang is also a good shooter but (obviously) he is the most dangerous in close combat - although his character clearly also is no more in his prime and will realise it during this mission...The other members of the team, Toll Road (ex-wrestler Randy Couture) and Hale Caesar (ex-footballer Terry Crews) have less screen time, but they also have their stories to tell and they add some flavour to the whole thing.Other than the names of some of the mercenaries, the big gag which I appreciated the most is that they all have deep and concerning issues: Ross has the aging problem, Christmas has a girlfriend problem, Jensen has an addiction problem, Yang has money troubles, Road has depression issues (and the whole cinema went amok with laughter when he confessed why) and Caesar has a fixation on absolutely enormous guns, which is most of the times a sign of..., well, you know what kind of problem...)))Stallone's team is assisted by a former soldier and mercenary known only as Tool (played by Mickey Rourke), who now is retired and earns his living officially by making tattoos to bikers and exotic dancers - but in fact he is a go-between arranging "jobs" for the mercenaries. Mickey Rourke gives in this movie a great performance and it is a pure pleasure watching him on the screen.This testosterone laced ensemble will have to face not only the usual hordes of evil gun fodder but also three particularly nasty bad guys: a fiendish former CIA agent turned free lance criminal (Eric Roberts) and his two vile and brutish henchmen: Paine (played by ex-wrestler "Stone Cold" Steve Austin) and Brit (played by kickboxer and martial arts expert Gary Daniels). The two apocalyptic close quarter fights between Ross and Paine and between Christmas, Yang and Brit towards the end of the movie are a particularly great treat. Martial arts shown in those duels are nothing like karate from Bruce Lee or Chuck Norris movies - they look rather like battlefield fighting styles (Israeli krav maga or Soviet sambo), very violent and brutal and designed to kill rather than to display one's ability.As almost everybody probably already knows there is one scene in the movie when Stallone meets Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis. This short scene takes place in a church - and I am almost certain that this is homage to the scene from Sergio Leone's most famous western, when the three heroes meet in a cemetery... Although short, the church scene is a simply incredible moment of cinema! In my modest opinion even if somebody got a Nobel Prize, found the cure for cancer or climbed Mount Everest wearing only strings, still his/her life is not complete without watching the church scene from "Expendables"...)))The cast is clearly impressive, but what makes this movie so enjoyable is the tone Stallone adopted for the whole movie. No matter how much we try, it is simply impossible to take this film seriously. The violence is certainly omnipresent and very graphic, but it is also so exaggerated that it finally starts to have an almost comic effect. Stallone also took care to soften the violence of fights by giving the "bad guys" face paintings which make them look more like plastic figures than real human beings - which gave as final result more the impression of a video game for teenagers than a real fight.Another great thing is that this movie has many surprisingly touching and even tender moments. Stallone did a good choice by giving his character a soft touch: as he gets old he clearly regrets less his youth than the fact that he does not have any family, other than the handful of desperados he hangs with. He also clearly has some bad things on the conscience and as his life enters its last stage, he longs for some redemption. This is why Ross decides to commit himself so heavily in this "job" - not only to earn his wage, but also to save an innocent person... who reminds him of a daughter he never had... And finally the relation between the whole team (and Tool) reminds one of an extended family or tribe reunion - with Rourke and Stallone playing the role of aging tribal ancestors, watching with tender care (and also some concern) their young and not so young braves.I enjoyed this movie greatly and I really hope that there will be a sequel - if possible with Chuck Norris making at least one cameo! Another great idea somebody launched on internet is an "oestrogen" version of "Expendables" - a remake with an exclusively feminine cast, with Sigourney Weaver, Lucy Lawless and Michelle Yeoh taking Stallone, Lundgren and Jet Li roles... )))The title of this review (which was inspired by a not so good Mel Gibson's movie) reflects quite well my feelings, when I left the cinema. This movie - and especially the ending - made me feel some nostalgia, gave me a lot of fun, but it also made me feel good. I will certainly buy the DVD as soon as it is available and I will watch it again from time to time to remind me of the old good action movies from the 80s, a time when I was an action movie fan... and young!
summary: "We were action heroes once... and young..."

reviewText: I love action films. I've always been a sucker for those movies that featured larger than life heroes taking on all odds to beat the bad guys. When those movies changed to feature heroes that were not always quite pure I still loved seeing them. When THE EXPENDABLES was released featuring not one but a number of action heroes on screen together I thought it was fantastic. This hadn't been done since the sixties when films like THE GREAT ESCAPE or THE DIRTY DOZEN were made.If you haven't seen the movie it tells the story of Barney Ross (Sylvester Stallone), the leader of a crew of for hire mercenaries that take on almost any job. The film opens with them rescuing a group of people taken hostage by pirates. Barney and his crew offer them the option to leave peacefully once and when they refuse they are all taken out with "extreme prejudice", graphically so. But when one of his team goes too far, even Barney sets him aside and refuses to use him on their next mission until he cleans himself up mentally.Getting that next mission is fun in itself. Barney meets with a mysterious stranger played by Bruce Willis in a church. Willis has also called in someone else to offer them the job played by Arnold Schwarzenegger. Seeing these three icons of action films on the screen at the same time is a rare treat. Arnold turns the job down but Ross decides to recon the situation and see if it's possible to achieve.Taking his right hand man Lee Christmas (Jason Statham) with him, they scope out the small South American island that's run by a small time dictator being propped up by an ex-CIA agent (Eric Roberts) whose using the people and the island for his drug operation. The people on the island, led by the dictator's daughter Sandra, are hoping to revolt. Ross figures out that his contractor is probably CIA and wants to control the island for the company. But something about the woman's resolve to stay on the island and try to make it better touches him. He and Christmas escape from the island after nearly being caught and he makes the decision to take on the job.The team of the Expendables includes Toll Road (Randy Coutre), Hale Caesar (Terry Crews) and Yin Yang (Jet Li) along with Ross and Christmas. Each has their own specialty in fighting technique and all will come in handy as they face off against Roberts men on the island which include WWE star Stone Cold Steve Austin and martial arts star Gary Daniels. These include some of the best fight scenes ever filmed.The movie is filled with explosions, fight scenes and heroic turns of events that make these mercs more human than most that shows a caring side to them as well as the hire for money side. You also witness a camaraderie and loyalty among the group that is rare in films these days. But most of all you have one of the best most high octane action films made in years.Having been a while since I saw the film originally I wasn't sure at first what made this extended cut different. In retrospect I realized that there was more background and involvement with the entire crew, including part time member Mickey Rourke, than there was in the original release. This fills out the team better than at first and makes them more interesting as well.Work on the sequel has already begun and more testosterone has been added by including both Chuck Norris and Jean-Claude Van Damme as well. The only action hero that seems to be missing is Steven Segal and Danny Trejo but maybe they'll be around for a third film, who knows?

reviewText: I figured I would give Sylvester another go after hearing good things about this movie.  All I can say is, it is what it is.  The Expendables is meant to be a pure action movie.  There is a plot, though you really can't figure out what it is. Ladies be warned, if enough of us men get together and watch this the testosterone alone is going to destory the house.When people told me this movie was low budget, I had really expected worse.  I must say that I was surprised with how it all turned out.  Sure it wasn't the best, but 90% of the scenes were extremely well done and most of the action was maxed out.  A bit of a slow start but once it gets to rolling it doesn't stop.  I was disappointed in the star-studded cast.  The meeting between Bruce Willis, Stallone and Schwarzenegger seems to be more of an empty gesture to fans.  Expendables could have existed fine without this scene and it is confusing, seems to be a space filler, and just an opprotunity to give Willis and the Governator a few seconds of time. Statham did his usual five star job, Jet Li was the kind of character you just have to love, and Rourke was off the chain entertaining as a tattoo artist bad a** named Tool.  Steve Austin?  Awesome actor, baaaaaaad character.  The rest of the line up seem to be supporting cast.If you want something that will blow your windows out when it comes through your surround sound, something that men can get together and eat beef jerky while watching and then go out and shoot up the neighborhood road side trash cans then this is it.  Gotta be in the right company to enjoy.  Personally I would give it 4 stars but I'm going by this: Can just anyone pick this up and truly be entertained?  I don't think so.

reviewText: "The Expendables" is an action film that's less about the action and more about the 80s retread cast.  Where else can Rocky (Sylvester Stallone) and Ivan Drago (Dolph Lundgren) face off once more? Or watch Jet Li face off against Lundgren? Or witness Jason Statham compete in a knife throwing contest with Stallone? Or watch Mickey Rourke lecture Stallone? Or listen to Bruce Willis, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Stallone quip wise in a church? Nowhere else!  Depending on whether or not you find these kinds of face-offs intriguing will determine your level of interest in this film.That's it.  The characters' names and back stories mean less to the film than the actors themselves, whose legendary oeuvre make it impossible to see them as anything else. This is not a film where Jet Li plays the demolitions expert and Stallone is the martial artist.  Everyone fits comfortably back into their own roles like a well-worn glove and embraces it with gusto as they take on the actor known for arch-villainy across all of Syfy-dom, Eric Roberts.Our motley team of mercenaries belongs to a biker gang known as The Expendables, based in New Orleans. There's the leader Barney Ross (Sylvester Stallone), stabby guy Lee Christmas (Jason Statham), martial artist Yin Yang (Jet Li), sniper Gunnar Jensen (Dolph Lundgren), heavy weapons guy Hale Caesar (Terry Crews) and blow-things-up guy Toll Road (Randy Couture). Their workaday rhythm of blasting bad guys goes south when Jensen loses it during a mission and Christmas discovers his girlfriend (Charisma Carpenter) has left him for another man. That's what passes for character development.In an aging warrior dialogue reminiscent of Frank Miller's "The Dark Knight Returns," Ross wears his military mantle with a heavy brow.  He no longer fights for anything - it's part of being a mercenary after all - and without family to speak of he longs to be passionate about something, lest he turn into a raving psychopath like Jensen. The film reaches its spiritual apex in a dialogue between Ross and Tool (Mickey Rourke), who does more acting in five minutes than the entire crew manages in the rest of the movie. Can our hero find redemption?Ross finds hope in spunky Sandra (Gisele Itie) who ferociously resists dictator General Garza (David Zayas, subdued here) in the South American island nation of Vilena. Of course, there's always an evil American behind all this, and unrepentant ex-CIA officer James Monroe (Eric Roberts) pulls the puppet strings. Even with Paine (Steve Austin) and the Brit (Gary Daniels) amongst his troops, Monroe doesn't have a chance.If you can't guess how this is going to end then you haven't seen many action movies. Suffice it to say that dictators are overthrown, buildings are blown up, and souls are saved. Along the way villains are shot, sliced, stabbed, crushed, and burned alive.  The dialogue is occasionally funny (Yang complaining about how he has to get paid more because he works harder due to his small stature really cracked me up), the violence always intense, and the pace never, ever slows down.  "The Expendables" doesn't aim very high but hits the bulls-eye anyway as an action flick that's all action.

reviewText: Ever since the emergence of the first modern, high-profile action heroes, fans like me have been clamoring for collaborations between the top names, and now - after almost three decades of fantasizing about heroic team-ups and who-would-win scenarios, director Sylvester Stallone makes this a reality. Sure, he had to forego on a few names that should've been in the movie (e.g. Jean-Claude Van Damme, Steven Seagal, Kurt Russell, Scott Adkins) and yes, expectations for this picture likely ran so high that it was impossible to satisfy everybody out there, but the fact is that Stallone has managed to make those names he did get to swallow their pride and be sized up alongside eachother. It's a feat in moviemaking that other features only inched towards but which Stallone not only accomplished but made look good. This is, without a doubt, required viewing for all general action fans.The story: an expert team of no-fail mercenaries - Barney Ross (Sylvester Stallone,Rocky series), Lee Christmas (Jason Statham,The Transporterseries), Ying Yang (Jet Li,Hero), Toll Road (MMA star Randy Couture), and Hale Caesar (football hero Terry Crews) - is called upon to overthrow the dictator of a small South American island (David Zayas,Dexter)...unaware that their target is backed not only by a corrupt US official (Eric Roberts) but also an unbalanced former teammate of theirs (Dolph Lundgren,Universal Soldier).The movie is notable for many promotional reasons, not the least of which for featuring a true supergroup of legitimate action stars from an array of cinematic disciplines. What appealed to me the most, however, is that it's a return to the ring for several cast members who have been estranged from big budget films for some time. You could argue this for the likes of Stallone, Mickey Rourke, and cameo man Arnold Schwarzenegger, but hey, they've either already made their comeback or continue to enjoy publicity. Eric Roberts has had to slog his way through too many dastardly DTV titles, but since he was inThe Dark Knight, I can't feel too sorry for him. No, the real surprise entries to the cast are the Swedish Superman Dolph Lundgren and B-movie dragon Gary Daniels as one of Munroe's main bodyguards, alongside Steve Austin. Since his last theatrical feature of 15 years ago, Lundgren has become somewhat of a cornerstone of the low-budget action market, supplying hit-or-miss titles alongside Seagal and Van Damme but never really losing his credibility and always looking ready for a comeback. This is only the second film of Daniels' to see a theatrical release, because for some reason, this martial arts wizard has found himself saddled almost exclusively with sub-par scripts and directors; sure,Bloodmoonwas awesome, but it's about time he saw some high-profile action again...and what could be more high-profile than fighting Jet Li and Jason Statham at the same time? Kudos to director Stallone for these picks.Upon hearing of its existence, my hopes for the film's action content were so high that, realistically, they were impossible to meet, but I'd still say that the movie's gunfights, brawls, and chases are easily among the most pleasing I've seen this year. Again, there's a lot to be said for the out-of-the-blue adrenaline pieces (e.g. Statham riding the nose of a plane and absolutely destroying the posse of his girlfriend's abusive ex, Crews wielding a machinegun firing explosive rounds, Stallone and Statham taking out a gang of soldiers with guns and many, many knives), but I found the most appeal in a specific area: the decisive match-ups between the credited cast members. In the past, we've only occasionally been able to enjoy showdowns between two high-profile stars (e.g. Stallone vs. Wesley Snipes,Demolition Man), but more often than not, big names are wary of taking on other big names for fear of appearing inferior. While we do miss out on seeing Stallone taking on either Bruce Willis or Schwarzenegger in anything but a verbal joust, the film does supply us with promising hand-to-hand encounters of Stallone vs. Austin, Austin vs. Couture, Daniels vs. Li & Statham, and Li vs. Lundgren. Not content to give viewers the usual cop-out, director Stallone presents us with real winners and losers...even making himself one of the latter. The Li/Lundgren fight is both my personal favorite of the bunch and a good example of this: though it could've been longer, it's an unbarred martial arts encounter with both performers getting to show off their respective fighting styles - Li as the leaping wushu wizard, Lundgren as the stand-up karate powerhouse - before showing, without a doubt, who the superior warrior is. Fans will be shocked but likely satisfied.The one aspect where the movie really falters, though, is in fleshing out its characters...or rather, fleshing out some characters as much as others. This was probably unavoidable, considering how saturated with big names this one is, but it's still disappointing to see some folks billed decisively above others. Stallone and Statham are presented as the upfront stars of the feature, getting more screentime than anybody else and possessing the most personality. Roberts is almost always presented more impressively than David Zayas, and Steve Austin almost makes Gary Daniels forgettable by comparison. Lundgren is excellent as a crazy villain and therein much more interesting than rival Jet Li, who is still afforded more characterization than Couture and Crews, both of whom can't have more than three scenes apiece in which they're not fighting. It's amazing that, in the midst of all this, the movie still had time to establish Mexican TV star Giselle Itie as an entrant to American cinema...but then again, it managed probably managed so by skimping on the role of Christmas' ex (Charisma Carpenter,Angel).Production values are strong, especially considering the wide scope of the film and the variety of its locales, although the graphics involved when Steven Austin is set on fire looked a bit unconvincing to me. If you're hip to action movies, I needn't comment too much on the acting, which is okay in terms of guys like Zayas, Li, and Statham, pretty good by Stallone, Roberts, and Lundgren, and very satisfying during a couple of Rourke's scenes. While I was disappointed that the film seemed to have been made more in the mindset of general Hollywood-style productions rather than 80s/early-90s B-movie ham, it speaks a universal language in terms of big guns, big guys, and big fights, so even a fan of low-budget fare like me can't complain too much. "The Expendables" really is the action opus extravaganza we've been wishing for for all these years; whether or not you enjoy it as an action fan is whether you were careful about what you wished for.

reviewText: Don't let my three star review fool you, The Expendables is a fun acton movie and I would give it another half star if I could, but it didn't quite deliver as much as it could have. I don't know why, but to simply put it, some of the toughness felt forced. You have all this top calibur celluloid muscle in need of better material. I know the story and dialogue are suppose to be cheesy and cliche, but Sylvester Stallone couldn't even write anything memorable for the much talked about cameos of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis. I have to admit that the line Stallone says to Arnold as he's leaving is great and easily the best of the movie. Believe it or not, I think a longer version would make it better. There are too many main characters that we learn little to nothing about. I hope we get an extended DVD release in the future.The cast is all about tearing people to shreds using various tools of death and as far as this genre goes, we have the best of the best on display. Stallone is solid, but Jason Statham is the standout. I also liked Mickey Rourke, who is easily the most natural actor of the bunch. Jet Li had a couple of good lines and fight scenes, while Terry Crews uses the most devasting handheld gun on film since the minigun wielded by Jesse Ventura in Predator and Arnold in Terminator 2. I do have to give credit to Dolph Lundgren, who I thought would be horrible, for turning in the scariest performance in the movie.If I were to pick my favorite pure action movies of the summer, I would have to go with Predators first, closely followed by The Expendables. Overall, it's a good throwback to the 80's, with plenty of gore, violence, and a body count way too extreme to ever try and calculate.3 and 1/2 out of 5 stars

reviewText: The way Stallone recently brought both ROCKY and RAMBO full circle and ended those iconic film series on a good strong note with a solid note of finality was masterful.5 stars to both ROCKY BALBOA-2007 and JOHN RAMBO-2008But EXPENDABLES ?????Hmmmm ...I know it was supposed to be a sort of not-too-serious homage to the action movies of the 80s, but for some reason it did not HIT me the same way the last ROCKY and RAMBO did.Maybe I have reached a point in life where I can only appreciate a movie if there is some sort of deeper message I can relate to based on my own experiences.Perhaps I don't get excited about fireworks (literally I don't), big explosions, gunfights, fistfights and car chases like I did when I was 16 years old.For whatever reason, when it came to EXPENDABLES I could not help but feel that the reason there was so much hype and buzz about the movie was the very special assembled cast of big names.Looking at the 5 minutes of plot and 101 minutes of POW -- BOOM --- WHAM,  I can't help but feel if this exact movie had been made with any other group of actors it would have been overlooked and dismissed as just another forgettable and generic action movie.This movie does have a magic, but it is because of the assembled cast led by Stallone.With any other random cast of actors, the movie would probably not seem as special.EXPENDABLES has lots of flash and energy, but not the same soul as other Stallone movies of recent years.In all fairness, perhaps it is not intended to be really deep.  Perhaps it is intended to be pure escapism action, action, action.If that is the case, the fault is not with the movie itself, but with my frame of mind or expectations I may have had following ROCKY BALBOA and JOHN RAMBO.(both movies that had action but also a deeper meaningful message one can relate to).Note -- I think the scene with Rocky talking to his son outside the restaurant in RB, is one of the most powerful scenes in all of Stallone's movies.I am a big Stallone fan.I respect the guy personally and professionally.Tons of hard work went into making this film that must be respected.We watch his films like ROCKY BALBOA-2007, JOHN RAMBO-2008, Cliffhanger, Get Carter, Lock Up and others at least once per year each at our house.But in the case of EXPENDABLES, while we have added it to our Blu-Ray collection,  I don't think it will be viewed quite as often in the future as our other favorite Sly films.It may just be my tastes changing as I get older that has effected my feel for this particular film.If I shift my mind into a pure action film mentality (the same mentality I may have had 25 years ago watching Arnold's COMMANDO),  I may end up rating this movie higher...  but mentally I'm not that same young guy anymore either.Yeah .....  I think that is a fair analysis.Lastly,I will confess, I think I may have enjoyed the two Blu-Ray bonus feature documentaries INFERNO (the filming)  and FROM THE ASHES (post production)  as much or more than the movie itself.It is interesting for somebody not actively involved in the film making business to see an extensive behind the scenes look at all the work that goes into making a 90 minute film.Yes, we all know you need a script, screenplay, set design, wardrobe, shoot scenes, music soundtracks, editing, etc...We all know the basic concept of how movies are made..... but as an analogy,  there is a difference between knowing how a car works in theory and being able to build one yourself from scratch.The two bonus feature documentaries on the Expendables Blu-Ray go into good detail on the whole process from beginning to end.As good as the movie itself for me personally.

reviewText: Those going into The Expendables should know what they're getting beforehand: a knock-down, over the top 80s throwback action blast that represents some of the best qualities of the 80s action flicks that star/director Sylvester Stallone made famous.  Stallone stars as Barney, leader of a team of mercenaries (which also includes Jason Statham, Jet Li, Terry Crews, Randy Couture, and Dolph Lundgren) that gets way in over their heads when employed to overthrow a South American dictator (Dexter's David Zayas) and the beyond bad crew (Eric Roberts and Steve Austin) pulling the strings behind the scenes.  Story and dialogue take second place to the action sequences, which are wonderfully orchestrated and filmed, yet nowhere near as graphic or gut-churning as what Stallone managed to pump out with 2008s Rambo.  Not to mention the fact that there are more than a few moments where the film takes itself too seriously, which does detract from the overall notion that this is a bona-fide guilty pleasure kind of action movie that boasts the best throwback action cast, well, maybe ever.  Like I said, if the aforementioned cast members aren't enough for you, how about Mickey Rourke, Gary Daniels, and unbilled cameos from Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger?  Or ample eye-candy in the form of Giselle Itie and Charisma Carpenter?  There's just so many feel-good aspects about The Expendables that it soon becomes easy to overlook its flaws, and that in itself is nothing less than an achievement.  All in all, if you don't get any amount of enjoyment out of The Expendables, you should check your pulse at the very least.
summary: Over the top 80s throwback action? Sign me up.

reviewText: I grabbed this movie hoping for some good, fun, over-the-top action, but I have to say that it failed to deliver. The biggest reason why is that there are just too many characters! While Stallone and Statham are clearly "the stars," there are also over a dozen other "supporting stars" -- and The Expendables has to give each one of those stars enough screen time to establish his character, to make us like him enough that we care if he lives or dies, and to let him feature in at least one cool scene. That's a HUGE chunk of time spent doing nothing but rolling out characters. It didn't add anything to the plot (mainly because there WAS no plot), while it really cut into the action.And even when there was good action, the director filmed the biggest scenes in the dark, using shaky-cams. So I could tell that someone was shooting, but didn't have a prayer of figuring out who was shooting who. The introductory hostage rescue, and the assault at the end, both suffered from this. My TV has pretty good contrast, but I don't like having to rewind every 60 seconds to figure out what just happened.The remaining action scenes were good, mind you! A solid car chase or two, some nice martial arts action, and even an old-fashioned streetfight on a basketball court -- all the kind of stuff I expected. If the whole film were able to keep that level of over-the-top, cinematic action, it would've been great.(Alternatively, it could've had a good plot, instead of one that made absolutely no sense. "The villain kidnaps the girl before escaping -- why? Uh... because he's the villain and that's just what they do!" Heh. But that's secondary at best. No one goes into The Expendables expecting a strong plot -- we want crazy action! I just wish I'd gotten it.)

reviewText: It is rare I do a review on a movie this soon after being on DVD but,alas,miracles do happen and here I am.The Expendables released in August/10 stars many major and minor action stars of the present and past including Bruce Willis,Arnold Schwarzenegger,Sylvester Stallone,Jet Li,Dolph Lundgren,Steve Austin,Mickey Rourke,Eric Roberts,Jason Statham,Terry Crews and Randy Couture.I was  disappointed in this film because with all these actors I had very high expectations;maybe too high. Stallone's direction I thought was acceptable,as was the plot.The story which is as see through as silk stockings,starts with a hostage taking on a ship off of Africa(some might argue Mr Stallone is keeped it direct,but simple).Stallone leads a mercenary team to the rescue and does it with quick dispatch.However team member Gunner played by Lundgren(doing his fave psycho-soldier routine from Universal Soldier)goes a little over the top when he wants to hang one of the pirate hostage takers.He's stopped and is summarily kicked off the team for being untrustworthy.Back home team leader Barney(Stallone) is summoned to a meeting with a Mr.Church(Willis)in a....where else?..church.At the same time he has invited an old rival of Barney's called Trent(Schwarzenegger)to outbid Barney,if he's so inclined,for the job.The job is to go to an imaginary island called Vilena in the Gulf of Mexico to overthrow the dictator there.Trent tells Church to give the job to Barney as he "likes to play in the jungle"(referencing his Rambo days)and walks out.Church asks Barney what Trent's problem is and he replies"He wants to be President"(referencing his current political life).Barney and a small reconnaissance team suss out the island and barely escape with their lives.It seems the man pulling the dictators strings is an ex CIA agent gone rogue called Munroe.Barney now knows that the real target is Munroe not the dictator.However he had a brief encounter with the dictators daughter on the island who is vehemently opposed to her fathers rule but elected to stay behind when given the chance to leave.He can't get her out of his mind and decides to return to rescue her,without his team.But the team elects to follow their leader and a long and bitter struggle ensues with Stallone killing Munroe and ending the reign of terror on Vilena.This film is not much more than the window dressing that covers it,or a book with a lovely dust jacket with nothing inside,if you will.We have all these well known actors,buffed up,with testosterone oozing everywhere and nothing much at all to do or say;and what they do say and do is predictable and sometimes unappealing.But what,in the end,Stallone brought these guys together to do,he succeeds in tremendously.This group of guys is not here to do Shakespeare or to win Academy Awards.Stallone knows the appeal of the action film genre,as he has been part of it for most of his career,along with all the others on board.No,action and only action,INTENSE action,action BEYOND action,is what is served up in large dollops here.And I think most guys would agree,it went down mighty good.The action is not for the feint of heart,with over the top explosions,kills and lots and lots of blood and gore.Also,think about this aspect of Stallone's train of thought re making this movie in the first place.Not only will the film attract HIS fans,but also those of each and every other action man on board this film.This is a film that could not help but be a win,win at the box office.Mr Stallone is NO dummy folks.The film is about 103 minutes long and comes in its 2:35:1 widescreen format.The transfer has been well done and the Dolby 5.1 sound is very good.Extras include an audio commentary by Stallone,a making-of featurette,deleted scenes,a gag reel & trailers,on the Blu-Ray copy only.The DVD copy has just the trailer as an extra,and there is the digital copy for your computer.In conclusion what should have been a great send up of past action movies with a heavy hitting cast,the likes of which you rarely see,was a little disappointing.However Stallone and company did deliver the INTENSE action they set out to,just not at the level I thought they could and should have.This combo pack is certainly a good buy.3 1/2 stars.

reviewText: The Expendables (Sylvester Stallone, 2010)Ten minutes into The Expendables things had already gotten so unbelievable that I asked myself why I was watching this low-rent-but-all-star take on one of my all-time favorite movies, The Dogs of War. But that very unbelievability made it stupidly entertaining enough that I kept going and discovered the movie's few treasures, though most of it is exactly the kind of mindless, predictable action-comedy that I figured I was getting when I went in.That unbelievable opening scene involves our group of Expendables--Barney Ross (Stallone), Lee Christmas (Jason Statham), Yin Yang (Jet Li), Gunnar Jensen (Dolph Lundgren), Hale Caesar (Terry Crews), and Toll Road (Randy Couture)--rescuing a bunch of hostages from Somalian pirates (led by The Mist's Amin Joseph). The ridiculousness comes from all the bullets flying around and not a single civilian casualty. Amazing how that works! Afterwards, there's a brief scuffle between Yang and the less-ethical Jensen. Jensen departs the group, who are soon after hired by a nameless guy calling himself Mr. Church (Bruce Willis) who wants a Central American dictator, General Garza (Dexter's David Zayas), overthrown, and is willing to offer the job to either Barney's bunch or another band of mercenaries led by Trench (Arnold Schwarzenegger in his first screen appearance since 2004, albeit in a cameo). Barney and co. get the job and head off to meet their in-country contact, Sandra (On the Road's Giselle Itié), and get to overthrowin'. Problem is, the General is both backed by a guy who may or may not be a CIA operative (The Dark Knight's Eric Roberts) and surrounded by mercenaries himself, ruled by the sadistic Paine (Steve Austin)... and including Jensen, who was with the group long enough to be able to anticipate most of Barney's moves.You will most likely be able to map out the way the entire movie unfolds by the end of the scene with Willis, Stallone, and Schwarzie. Which, as long as you're looking for a brainless action movie, is perfectly okay--but with so many obvious references to the single greatest action movie ever created combined with so many big-huge-massive-name action stars, and I am perfectly willing to admit this may be my problem and not the movie's, I was expecting something more than I got, something like that life-shattering twist where Christopher Walken marches into the new dictator's office as if he's simply going to demand the money he's owed and... does what he does that leaves your jaw sitting on the floor in a drool pool. Or, you know, even a halfway intelligent script that didn't sacrifice brains for one-liners every chance it got. (And this is where those "few treasures" come in--all of them involve Tool's Bar, where the gang hangs out during downtime; Tool, played by Mickey Rourke, is kind of the group's Yoda, and he is easily the best thing about the film.) But if you take it for what it is, it fulfills its role adequately. **

reviewText: Released exclusively on Blu-ray, like Stallone's previous director's edition of his last (John) Rambo film. Any paying patron will pretty much know what to expect from the movie itself, having most likely already seen the previously released theatrical cut. So, the question to be answered is how does this version differ and is it worth the extra dough to add to one's collection.Assembling an impressive cast of veteran tough guys and action stars, Sly Stallone co-wrote, directed and stars alongside Jason Stahtam, Jet Li, Mickey Rourke, Dolph Lundgren, Eric Roberts, Randy Couture, "Stone Cold" Steve Austin,  Gary Daniels, Terry Crews, and with cameos from the likes of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis. This is a big, dumb movie of the highest order, who could ask for anything more. Arcing back to the days when action flicks were about brute force, well trained stuntmen and correctly timed charges. None of this nancy boy CGI wire effects that can turn even the meekest of movie stars into a superhero. Don't worry about plot, all we need is just enough dialogue to get us from one gun battle to the next.As it is, I enjoyed the theatrical version when I saw when it was first released a couple of years ago in a throwback to the days of my boyhood when I greatly anticipated each and every new film from these stars. The new extended cut is according to Sly himself in an introduction before the movie "better than the theatrical, has more content, more heart and is closer to it's original intent." Okay, I don't know about all that, but what I can tell you is that this version is longer, cooler, more violent and makes better use of music. Still, the rough edges of a rush production are as evident as before.We see, or rather hear the new additions right up front with a giddily corny voice over introduction by Stallone's Barney Ross character that does nothing for the flick. However, we quickly get an extended action scene. There is far more humor to this version, I loved all the talk of Lundgren's Viking beliefs and funerals, and Sly and the Stath are awarded more amiable banter. Couture and Crews, who were short changed in the theatrical release, here get at least a little more screen time,  character development and more full monologues. There are a few additional dramatic moments offered to Statham and love interest Charisma Carpenter, that like dramatic scenes from earlier Stallone directed films comes across awkward with wobbly performances. And yes, more action. The best addition pervaded here is the use of music, from the different opening titles unfolding over Sully Erna (of Godsmack)'s moody "Sinner's Prayer" to the successful inclusion of Shinedown's "Diamond Eyes", so popular in the movie's trailer, played over the final showdown sequence.A significant improvement, I would actually say. A more fully rounded, fun and entertaining adventure film. The Blu-ray has a bunch of cool bonus features, the best being the feature length documentary Inferno: the Making of the Expendables, that is well worth checking out.check out my reviews at moviezonemagazine.com
summary: Even better the second time around

reviewText: I was discussing the new Director's Cut of The Expendables with a friend, and found myself using the same word to describe it: interesting.  Not "better" or "improved," just... interesting. To an even larger degree than he did with the "Rambo" director's cut, Stallone has not just added deleted footage into the movie. He has re-edited a great deal of the movie. It's eleven minutes longer, but that hardly describes the reworking The Expendables has received.I really liked The Expendables theatrical cut and thought it was a fun blast of macho action. The Blu-ray release is loaded with tons of great stuff - including the fantastic feature-length documentary "Inferno" - that really deepened my appreciated for the huge effort that Stallone and company invented in this movie. I didn't think it was without flaws though. Possibly the main one was an overall lack of depth to the lead character, Stallone's Barney Ross. I chalked it up to the fact that Stallone was wearing a lot of hats on this one (actor, writer, director) and also working with a relatively low budget (as far as these types of movies go, anyway).I also agreed that with the large number of supporting characters, many of them got somewhat short-changed - especially Jet Li, who is one of the main stars. The main story felt a little clumsily told as well. It seemed like a director's cut was a very good idea. And Stallone says in the introduction, "I liked the theatrical version, but I love this." So naturally it only makes sense to compare to two versions.For better or worse, I would say they are the same but different. The same in the sense that nothing has really changed about the way the story is told (and that the story itself isn't very imaginative or original). There's still a ton of characters, most of them receiving only very minor expansions if at all. This includes Jet Li, who still feels underused. It's kind of like if an author wrote a good book, then decided to go through and reword the majority of it without really altering the content of the story. The Director's Cut of "The Expendables" is an alternate way of looking at basically the same movie.Some of the violence has actually been toned down, with little trims made here and there to the bloodier scenes. Certain lines of dialogue - such as Jason Statham receiving a text message during a siege on pirates near the beginning - have been cut entirely. Mickey Rourke's great monologue has been subtly trimmed - just enough to change the pacing, which was perfect to begin with. Lee's girlfriend Lacey (Charisma Carpenter) has a much lighter bruise on her face when Lee goes to visit her - which is a puzzling change, considering the injury prompts a very violent retaliation by Lee against her assaulter. During the climatic action sequence, Brian Tyler's effective score has been replaced by a rock song.I'm not wild about any of these changes, but I don't think any of them would have changed my overall high level of enjoyment of the movie if this had been the version I first saw. That's what I mean by "same but different." The movie remains very entertaining, and I think I would have been equally satisfied with this version had it been released in theaters. But I don't think it really improves upon the version that was released.A few of the significant changes work really well.  The new opening credits sequence - complete with new music (a rock song, but this time it's a new sequence so we don't lose any of the score) - helps convey the weariness and isolation of the team of mercenaries. Much of the banter between Stallone's Barney Ross and Statham's Lee Christmas is expanded, which helps both characters. And some of the re-edited action scenes - especially the fight between Dolph Lundgren and Jet Li - are more visually dynamic and flow better.Overall it's a mixed bag, at least for me. I don't know which version I will be more likely to rewatch - though I know I'm more used to the theatrical cut. I barely touched on the vast number of differences between the two versions - I'm sure I didn't even catch everything, as many are very subtle. Big fans of the movie - or of Stallone in general - should definitely pick it up.  There are a couple of very cool new features, including a twenty minute featurette with Stallone talking about each movie he has directed.

reviewText: Honestly what would you expect out of a movie from Stallone and co? A sensitive drama? I think not. The Expendables puts together some the best and biggest action movie stars and delivers a classic 1980's testosterone fueled action movie. In fact it's very much as if you had a blank DVD/Blu-Ray and injected testosterone into it. If you're not a fan of action movies, don't bother. But if you are a fan of action movies in general and liked what some of these actors have previously done you're in for a good time my friend. On the other hand if you can't stand the over-machoism, 80s action movies, Sly, over the top action...Well you get it, this won't be for everyone. The Expendables takes us back to a time where heroes were really heroes, cheesy one liners, over the top action sequences...good stuff. There is definitely an audience for this type of film since the movie performed really well at the box office earning over $274 millions on an $82 million budget. The incredible cast is what got most viewers to see this film: Stallone, Li, Statham, Lundgren, Austin, Couture, Rourke, even Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger make appearances!The Expendables follows an elite group of mercenaries sent on a mission to Vilena an island near South America to beat up some bad guys and help the island get rid of their dictator. The storyline is simple but effective, as far as action movies goes this makes sense and it works, Stallone was never really known for his scripts anyway, fans expect him to deliver in the action department. I loved seeing Dolph Lundgren again, Statham was pretty badass, Stallone was great as always, Mikey Rourke was excellent in his role. Only "Stone Cold" Steve Austin was a bit of a let down, I mean I'm not a huge fan of his but he only had one god scene for the most part he was just standing around and paid to look tough. There's plenty of action and over the top moments to satisfy action fans I would say, don't expect everything to make sense, this is big old dumb action!I realize that The Expendables is not for everybody but if you miss the glory days of action movies like Rambo, Cobra, Die-Hard, Terminator and so on then this is something you want to see. Objectively, I don't think The Expendable deserves a full five star but being a fan of most of these actors and witnessing some of the glory days of action movies once more. If you're merely curious you should check it out as well but you should just know what to expect before. I loved seeing all these action big names together; it was quite an experience to say the least. Besides all the criticism that Stallone usually gets from critics, and the reviewers who didn't find it to their liking The Expendables was a movie that I really enjoyed, I found it to be much better than most action movies that are released today. If you liked the film you may be pleased to know that a sequel is apparently in the works. Rating: 4/5.Comment

reviewText: "The Expendables" is a sort of a throwback to the 80s-style action film making. It is about a good macho guy or guys with guns shooting (lots of) bad guys. The good guy has to complete one mission or more in the most disadvantageous circumstances. Those who have grown up with such films as "Commando" or "Die Hard" (the first one) know what I am trying to say.The difference is, "The Expendables" directed by Sylvester Stallone has a lot of "good" guys played by our favorite actors including Jason Statham and Jet Li. A mercenary team led by Barney Ross (Stallone) is hired to assassinate a dictator in a South American country, where a local rebel Sandra (Giselle Itié) assists them. That's it. There are a few twists in the story, but the storyline itself is simple.The film also features Steve Austin, Randy Couture, Terry Crews, Gary Daniels, Dolph Lundgren and Eric Roberts. Each fighter (and ex-fighter) has their own signature arsenal or abilities - knife, martial arts, demolition, and so on - and when action starts, they never fail to use them. Not all guys fight. Mickey Rourke appears as an ex-mercenary and tattoo artist delivering a moving speech. Though brief, two cameos Arnold Schwarzenegger and Bruce Willis are amusing.Perhaps "The Expendables" feature too many stars. Screen time for some actors (Gary Daniels and Jet Li) is too short. Charisma Carpenter appears as Statham's girlfriend, but she is wasted. Still "The Expendables" certainly delivers what it promises: a pure, old-school action, and it works.

reviewText: First, this was the WORST STORY I've seen in quite awhile. Just AWFUL. There's nothing at all compelling about it. Even the 2008 RAMBO remake had an infinitely more interesting and suspenseful story than The Expendables. It's like it was written by a 6th grader for a book report (yeah, I know Stallone wrote them both). We saw this movie the day after it opened and I counted no less than 6 people in our theater actually SLEEPING at various times before the final 30 minutes, when some action actually happens. There was even snoring 2 seats over from me! That's what a lackluster and forgettable storyline does to people sitting in a dark theater...It becomes VISUAL MELATONIN. It's really a shame too with such a great cast. Everyone brought their A-game to The Expendables, but they could only perform within the limits of the lame story.For example, a 20 min (+/-) "recon" trip to the Latin American island by Stallone & Statham? Really, now...PURE FILLER! The ONLY reason this was even in the story was because they "had" to meet the General's daughter and expand their "cause". And that's 20 minutes that woulda, coulda, shoulda been spent having gunfights and blowing crap up! Instead, you have to wait until they're actually leaving the island to get any kind of explosive action. So then they go home, regroup and return to the same freakin island to finish the job they woulda, coulda, shoulda just done on the initial trip. And once they began their assault on the island, there was at least 5 minutes of film devoted solely to the various Expendables characters simply running around setting explosive charges to some over-the-top Hollywoodesque heroic musical score! Seriously...They just continuously ran around setting charge after charge. It was like you had filmed your kids for 5 minutes just running around the neighborhood in their new Halloween costumes. After the first 15 or 20 sec it was comedic, although I'm sure it was never INTENDED to be...I was also duped into thinking Bruce Willis and The Governator were actually INVOLVED in the movie. Well, it was just HYPE. They have a brief meeting in a church and it's over. Stallone might as well have met with Spongebob Squarepants and Patrick Star in the church. So with that disappointment and the lame story continually failing to ignite any passion in the audience as well as the actors, The Expendables forever lost any chance to live up to the pre-release hype and actually be a 5-star movie.There are only TWO things that saved this movie from a 1 or 2-star rating: 1) The final 30 minutes that had the action that the rest of the movie was lacking and 2) the AA-12 automatic shotgun used by Terry Crews' character, "Hale Caesar". The fistfights, gunfights and explosions that happen in the final 30 minutes when the real assault takes place is what woulda, coulda, shoulda been taking place during the rest of the movie instead of what seemed like endless, BORING dialogue between Stallone & Statham...Stallone & Rourke...Statham & his love interest...Stallone & Statham & the General's daughter......UGGGHHHH!!! Just over and over and over the plot DIED into pool after pool of merciless drivel.Would I see The Expendables again? Well, I wouldn't PAY to see it again. As I said, the actors were all very good...Stallone and Lundgren were even exceptional. But Stallone has done enough movies that when he sat through a pre-release screening of this one, I wouldn't be surprised if he just stopped the film after 20 or 30 minutes and said, "C'mon guys...I thought we were making an ACTION FILM here!" Yeah, that's what I thought too. I really like all of these guys and saw them on the NYSE floor on CNBC a few days after the release just having a great time. And that FUN was what the terrible story here prevented from happening until the final 30 minutes. In fact, if you just walked into the theater after watching another movie and saw the final 30 minutes of The Expendables you'd think, "WOW! That must've been the BEST MOVIE of the summer!" On the other hand, if you go in at the beginning then you're likely to doze off a few times or even get up early and leave to go watch the ending of another movie in the same theater complex.And that's what really sucks about The Expendables...It only delivers a partial dose of what woulda, coulda, shoulda been with a cast like this. This isn't rocket science. You've assembled a top team of testosterone-filled bodies. Get the opening credits out of the way, then give them big guns, lots of ammo and blow everything up in sight right until the final credits roll. Instead, we got a boring story and sporadic action until the movie was about 2/3 over. Assuming there's an Expendables 2, I hope they really do it up right next time...This was their "mulligan".
summary: Woulda, Coulda, Shoulda Been So Much Mo Better

reviewText: Its great to see Stallone still kicking it at 63(now 64), and all the rest of the guys in there early mid 40's, and 50's except for Jason Statham who remains the young pup at 38. The movie has some solid moments, and the characters are very believable. Yet where is the main plot? Well i'm still asking myself this. Eric Roberts(usually known for his horrible performances)really does a great job as an American drug lord who goes in to liberate a small country somewhere close to Mexico. The only thing you really know is The Expendables get recruited by Bruce Willis who has a short but decent cameo with Stallone and the Legendary goveranator Arnold S. Basically they are sent there to take out this general but find out there is a little(very little) more to it when they rally the troops and find out they are extremely out numbered, but never fear they will find there way. The female informant on the island won't leave, mainly because its her home and she feels that its not necessary and that things will change. Well not leaving gets her totured, and also you find out she is the evil general's daughter, which isn't a spoiler OR much of a big suprise. Mickey Rourke plays a broken down veteran from the gang known as Tool, who tattoos up Stallone in the beginning and has a few other small appearances here and there, Rourke definitely being the best actor of the bunch does very well for the small part he's given. The rest of the guys just run through the motions and really play a very small part from an actors perspective but later on really get into the action. The fight sequences are planned out well enough, though, some of the editing will give you a seizure because the footage moves so fast from scene to scene you really can't tell who's beating up who, which is the way a lot of action films are directed these days.Well in summing up The Expendables all i can say is if your a hardcore old school fan of blowing things up without much of a story(much like Rambo) then this movie is definitely for you. Even though i think they are trying to break a record for number of explosions to occur in a film, for the oscars(ha), it should appeal to those who like this type of movie. I was very pleased to see such older veteran actors together even if it was for a short time. I would however like to see Arnold and Stallone take on a roll together, which i hear is a possibility in the near future, though what movie? No one yet knows. Arnold works out religiously everyday which is a great thing considering he's just behind Stallone at 63 years old. Statham and Jet Li should also really really get together, since there fighting styles are much the same and they steal much of the psychical action in the film. So lets hope for that as well. The rest of the characters including Dolph the dope Lundgren(who i must say is horrible in this movie) should just be happy i suppose that they were given a chance to be in a film to show off there skills. So all in all its a decent film that will appease to old school 80's action film fans, but leave the younger crowd saying, who's dad is that? I myself enjoyed most of it, but i could stand a little more substance from a plot perspective next time. Expendables 2? Come on its Stallone what do you think? :)Btw, i don't use names or tell a whole lot in detail as to not give away much of the movie. Although this pretty much sums it up lol.

reviewText: Sylvestor Stallone with 2 great franchises on his notched belt has finally come into his own as a consumate filmmaker with this brilliant western posing as an action film, 'THE EXPENDABLES'.  I never saw this film in the theatres and its probably better for it because the digital image on high definition DVD lets you see every action sequence crystal clear rather than blurred images.  With director of photography Jeffrey Kimball, Stallone has created the perfect testosterone experience by gathering the greatest action stars of the decade and putting them through seperate vignettes culminating into a climactic ballet of blood making the viewer panting for more.  And out of all this wonderful, blistering action, Stallone pulls off the greatest acting coup for Mickey Rourke as he slows the film down allowing Rourke to do a passionate three minute soliloquy on saving a life which not only shows Rourke's brilliance as an actor but Stallone's maturity as director and mentor to his actors.  With giving each action star except for second billed Jason Statham equal measure throughout its running time and a relentlessly evil performance by Eric Roberts, Stallone has delivered the best action film of this or any other year.  The DVD has an excellent audio commentary by Stallone and a great featurette on the making of the whole experience.  Highly recommended for action fans and lovers of excellent high octane rushes.
summary: Blistering Testosterone for the Digital Age.

reviewText: I mean, this is staple fare, the guy flick concocted from explosives, diesel fuel, and testosterone, the commodity that studios keep churning out because they keep making money. Get your checklist ready, this has it all: a way-cool chase scene, a bring-it-down-around-their-ears ending, badguy foot soldiers who die like flies, a guy who hits girls getting the tar whupped out of him, some wildly improbable but really big gun, and a big man-to-man mano-a-mano fight scene between the two boss badazzes. Throw in the noble loneliness of the tough-but-honest mercenary (close cousin to the prostitute with a heart of gold), a saveable babe, and lots of things exploding as soon as they catch fire - well, youd didn't come here for plausibility. This stands as yet another towering tribute to Utter Manliness and to those select few who sacrifice themselves on its altar, and have a blast doing it. Not that they'd actually ever confess to something as unmanly as having big fun with big-boy toys.A month from now, even the finest memory will have trouble distinguishing this from others of its genre. That's OK. This is all about doing the right thing here and now, so watch it here and now.-- wiredweird
